title: How to get good grades in college - Quora

response.answer_text: It took me a couple years of college to figure this out, but here's how I ended up getting good grades in my junior and senior years while still having ample time to party and have a social life. (I went to UCSB, a great academic institution and a great party). The first bit of advice I would give is to take classes that you have some interest in. Even the more 'boring' pre-requisite classes offer up some choice to the students of several classes that will fulfill that requirement. Choose the one that is most interesting to you. It's a lot easier to do well in a class if you are interested in the topics. If none of the classes seem remotely interesting to you, then perhaps this isn't a good time in your life to be going to college, as you should be somewhat eager to learn something. Now once you have your classes selected, ask yourself, what is your goal for each class. In general, my experience was that a bare minimum of effort was required to get a C in a class, only a moderate amount of effort was required to get a B in a class, but for most classes, an A took quite a significant amount of effort, perhaps double that of a B. In other words, the effort required to get each better grade often increases exponentially. So if a given class required 2 hours of attention/work per week to get a C, it may have only required 4 hours per week to get a B, but probably demanded around 8 to 12 hours per week to get an A. So, decide how important an A is to you vs. a B in a given class, and remember, unless you plan on going to grad school, your GPA doesn't really matter, just that you got your degree. That being said, pay attention to what is required to take more advanced classes in your major, because sometimes a given grade in a certain class can be very important in order to take the next class in the series, and you always want to leave yourself some margin for error in case you bomb the final or miscalculated how much work was really required. Now, this is how you strategize your time if you want to cut a few corners like I did. (If I hadn't cut those corners, the work load was large enough that I would have had zero social life outside of class). First, and most importantly, go to every class the first week and pay close attention. Get the syllabus and study it carefully. The syllabus for each class should outline the entire semester for you and allow you to start planning your investment of time into that specific class strategically. Put every quiz, mid-term, final, research paper and homework assignment that is due in your calendar and set a reminder for yourself. It is imperative that you do not miss any of these if you want at least a B. Every professor or student teacher is different, but they generally fall into one of two categories. Those who place more value and emphasis on the lecture and those who place more value and emphasis on the textbook/reading. I found that you can usually determine this pretty well after the first week of classes. For those that place more emphasis on the textbook, you may not need to pay as close attention during lecture, for the others, you may be able to skim the reading assignments if you just take good notes in the lectures. Don't skip classes where the lecture is the primary delivery tool of information for that professor. For the professors where the reading assignments or textbooks are the primary tool, you will often be able to tell because they spend most of their lecture reviewing the textbook and from this you can usually infer what parts of the textbook they place the most value in. The easiest classes are often ones where the professor is actually the, or one of the authors of the textbook you are reading because they will more or less duplicate the information in class. Also pay attention to the points structure and see if more value is placed on quizzes or homework assignments. Most teachers will lay this out for you right from the get go. I found that with a basic understanding of what was expected by each professor, which could be ascertained relatively easily after the first week, very little extra effort was needed to get at least a B in a given class. An A was usually much harder and more labor intensive to come by. Now when you take your first mid-term or get your first major homework assignment, you should be able to have a good feel for what that professor expects from you for the rest of the class. Even if you don't do well, at this point there should still be time for a course correction and many professors will not only be lenient, but will place a fair amount of weight into boosting someone's grade who shows improvement from this time on. So if you miscalculated a bit on whether the lecture or the textbook was more important, or how heavily weighted the quizzes and homework assignments were, this is the time to adjust. No two classes are the same and the above strategy works best for liberal arts classes. Hard science classes almost always build on previous information. So you really can't skip any steps there. Just for reference, I got straight C's my freshman year, but finished my senior year with a cumulative GPA of 3.5. There were a few classes that I was really interested in where I can say I went to every class, read and completed every assignment... Most classes I took, I at least cut a couple corners, but that gave me time to have a social life, party, explore and enjoy college, where I doubt I would have had any time to do that if I did everything that was assigned to me on a full time course load. Edit: One thing I forgot to mention but can provide a decent boost to a grade in a given class is the importance of the professor’s office hours. Don’t be afraid or intimidated to see your professor during their office hours (which most colleges and universities require their faculty to keep). First, if you are falling behind or not performing as well as you would have liked for a given class, your professor might be open to creative ideas to earn extra points/credit. Often these assignments aren’t very time or labor intensive and can often mean the difference between a B- and a solid B, or a B+ and an A-. Secondly, your professors are human, (and usually compassionate), and when they can put a face to a name in their class, when they’ve developed a personal relationship with someone, they are more likely to move you up a notch if you are on the cusp between two grades. Office hours are a great way to give your grades a little extra boost without much extra effort, they help you keep track of how you’re doing in a class, and, if you’re going to school for the right reasons, should be relatively enjoyable as you will be having a conversation with someone who is passionate enough about a subject you’re studying that they’ve made a career of it.

I graduated on honour roll from college twice - associates in humanities and then a bachelor's in business. For my BA, I graduated top of my major. I also have a professional certification as a Certified Payroll Professional (CPP), which I gained while working full time. Here's what worked for me: [1] Know that Sleep is Unimportant. Time is of the essence in school, and sleep is one of the biggest thieves. While sleep is important, learn to need less and less of it. No matter how early you get things out of the way, there will always be nights when you need to stay up. In college, I allotted 6 hours per night for sleep. I got 2 hours as soon as I walked through the door and then timed my bedtime so that I went to sleep only 4 hours before I needed to be up for my morning class.  This put more hours in my day to get more done, and staying up became a breeze. I also used Twitter and other social media to help me stay awake by engaging my followers in discussions about what I was studying. You'd be amazed to know how much this helps you remember things. [2] Find a Distraction. This seems like an unlikely thing to need in college, but find something that you look forward to doing every day, except school work. For me, I loved to write books and play video games. I used them as rewards for when I completed particular goals. Finished a whole night of studying or completed a whole project? Awesome! That last hour was me blasting away at video games as payment. [3] Join a Study Group. In college, I tutored students one-on-one and in study groups for a number of subjects. I taught everything ranging from finance to law. Not only did it help me stay on top of my work, but all my "students" passed all their courses as well. Sometimes you need information related to you in informal language, in a way that you can remember it. Too often textbooks don't do it and teachers don't know how. [4] Write Everything Down. I know a lot of show offs who claim they can remember everything and don't need to write it down. Well... none of them graduated with a higher GPA than I did. I will tell you what my teachers told me, "The weakest ink lasts longer than the strongest memory" and don't you ever forget it. In fact, write that down, too.  I typed all my lectures, so when exams came around I had all my notes to turn to. If you are doing technical and mathematical courses, writing down those formulas and calculations is super important. Even if you don't understand it, write it down anyway. You can figure it out later. [5] Buy a Laptop. I don't understand how people write all their notes by hand. It is a slow process. Buy a laptop and learn to type fast. I type at 70 words per minute. I got almost everything my teachers said word for word. I was the go-to person for notes in class. Everyone else wrote them down by hand. [6] Read Over as Soon as You Get Home. The first order of business when I got home (after my two hour nap) was to read over everything I had done in class that day. This really only takes an hour or two and helps to ensure that the notes stick while it's still fresh. You can also quickly correct any mistakes you might have made in your notes. This helps to keep the information familiar to you.  I went a step further by converting all my notes into cue cards. I used those to study for tests afterwards, so that I didn't need to re-read the whole thing. And I didn't have to be struggling to write them up for finals. [7] Three Time's the Charm. When I was in high school, my English teacher told me that our brains only retain 30% of information at a time, so we have to read things three times to score 90%. I don't know the science behind that, but I used that in my routine. My aim is always to interact with the information/material from class at least three times in three different forms. I don't count class time. That's my hidden number four to boost me up to as close to 100% as possible. So for instance, I might read over the notes in class (one), and then read the corresponding chapter in the textbook (two), followed by reading the powerpoint slides we used to get (three).  [8] Stay Single. Relationships are fun and nurturing, but obligations to partners often gets in the way of good grades. If you have a partner who gives you a lot of space and can actually help you or tutor you in school, then you've struck gold. Otherwise, that person will take up a huge chunk of your time.  I was a great student in my relationship in college. I scored amazing grades and my work was often used as quality samples for other students. But, when I broke up with my fiance, my grades got even better. I went from an A/B student to A s. [9] Take Care of Yourself. School is stressful. Boost those feel good hormones with exercise. It will also prevent you from getting that complacent beer gut that many people leave college with. College is a "sedentary" job. Get up and run. Go to the gym. Bike. Walk. Do anything but sit all day. Eat healthy and don't use college as an excuse to stock up on junk. The last thing you need is to feel sick the night before your finals. Take supplements to boost your immune system and cook with garlic.  In college, almost every month my group had the cold or flu. Everyone would catch it but me. Also, in the second year of my BA, the whole school came down with chicken pox. It spread through the class like wildfire. The guy behind me in class had it, and so did all my roommates. I didn't get it. So I walked into exams on top of my game, while so many people were itchy and miserable. [10] Be Proactive. It sounds simple, but one of the biggest mistake people made in my classes was to procrastinate. I was team lead for my group so they didn't have that luxury. If we got the outline for a project today, they could count on starting it tonight. At first, it annoyed the hell out of them, but they soon realised how less stressful it was to do things when we had time for it.  When the work load increased and everyone else was struggling to meet deadlines, our work was already handed in and we were tweeting and playing video games. Because our work was never rushed, we had time to do multiple revisions at our leisure and produced high quality work time and time again. One of our teachers actually got audited for giving us 100% on a final project in a course that had one of the highest failure rates. The audit failed to find any fault with her teaching or our project. We kept that A+. Feel free to reach out for additional advice regarding doing well in school. I currently mentor/tutor college students as a hobby.

I'm going to have a hard time topping Elizabeth H. Simmons's answer given she's a dean and sees hundreds if not thousands of students a year (Michigan State is a huge school). But, here's the perspective of a college student who almost failed his first year, turned it around, and graduated with a decent GPA. I went on to get a MBA at a top tier school graduating with high distinction. Here's what I learned: Balance your workload. Before registering for a class, do research as far as how much work is involved. That way, you can make sure you can meet the time commitments.Time management is vital. My freshman year, I had a bad case of FOMO (fear of missing out). I had to go to this party or that one. I didn't want to be the one to hear stories about my friends' epic time out. Bad idea. You procrastinate and jam yourself into a corner time wise. I was pretty depressed after my freshman year and realized I needed to structure my week. I set aside Sunday evening to Friday afternoon as school time. No parties. No staying out late. Me and my books. Friday night through Sunday afternoon, I'd go out with my friends.Stay caught up in your reading. Falling behind results in cramming and cramming results in crappy grades. Period.Doing the homework and suggested assignments is basically exam prep. Most professors take modified versions of problems you do in homework for exam problems.Figure out what your goals are before you take a class to determine how involved you'll be. Example: I needed to get good grades in physics but it wasn't core to my major. So, I spent little time in class, but learned from the textbook and did the problems. Aced the class, but didn't afford myself the opportunity to ask my professor, a world-class physicist, questions that would've expanded my knowledge.Sleep. A lot. You can't learn when you don't sleep. Get into a schedule. I started to wake up regularly regardless of when class started and go to the gym for a workout. That helped set the pace for the day.Avoid distractions when studying. Some friends, romantic interests, etc are all bad news when you need to focus. I essentially had two sets of friends: those I could study with and those I partied with. The overlap between those two groups was tiny. A lot of the time, I studied alone.For lab work, choose wisely. Having an idiot or screw around lab partner is a recipe for disaster. Make sure to pair up with someone who takes schoolwork as seriously as you do. I finally found a girl who was headed for the same major, super smart, easy to work with, and to boot, was super cute. I made sure we were in lab together. She saved my ass in lab more times than I can count. I helped her too. We both did great.In the end, with time management, a bit of forward planning, and judicious selection of friends, you can have the time of your life AND get good grades. That's what I figured out anyway. As far as my cute lab partner, nothing became of that because I was in a long-term relationship, but that's a different answer to a different question.

There are already some great answers here, but I'll give you some of my techniques. I had  a *very* simple strategy for doing well in college (undergrad and grad, both). It goes like this: "Go to class, do the work, study for the tests." I know, it sounds way too simple to actually help, but it works. If you're not in college yet, you'd be shocked how many kids either 1) don't go to class, 2) don't do the work, 3) don't study enough, or 4) cheat their way through. If you do any other those three things I listed, you're ahead of the game. If you do all three, you *will* get an A.  The following are some more details about how to actually accomplish these three things: 1) Go to class This one is easy. Get to class on time. Get a seat in third row in a desk near the edge. You want to sit here because you will be close enough that you'll be forced to pay attention (less phone usage), but not so close that you'll feel self-conscious. Even if you don't think you'll use them, take notes! Personally I remember about 50% of what I read, maybe 10% of what I hear, but I remember almost everything that I write down. 2) Do the workThis one is a little trickier. Don't just do the homework, understand it. That means don't wait until the night before to do the work. Start a few days early and make sure one of the TAs has office hours between the time you start and the due date. If you've been following "Go to class", you'll have some decent notes to help you on the homework. Often times the questions are pretty much laid out in the textbook somewhere so keep that handy. If you still are stuck, go to the TA. I never did this much, but I know a lot of people who did and they found it very helpful. Another option is to find someone to work on the homework with. In my experience, though, if you've been going to class from the start, taking notes, learning the material, the homework will not be anything too difficult. 3) Study for the testsThis one is obvious, but people really don't take it seriously enough. Study, study, study! I have a rule when it comes to exams and I want you to really let this one sink in: "You should not be thinking during the exam" or, put another way, "Homework is for thinking, exams are for doing". If you find yourself "learning" something new on the test, you didn't study enough. Too many students will go to exams having only studied the night before (or not at all) and hope to "figure it out" as they go. To be completely honest, even I've done this strategy before. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't, but it is never a good experience. Ask your questions, make your mistakes, do your actual thinking during the homeworks. The exams will not be anything too different from what you've already learned and worked on (it wouldn't be fair otherwise!), so use the homeworks as your prep. You want to go into this exam knowing the material so well that you could do it in 10 minutes. How do you this? Keep reading. -> Read your notes at least *three times*. Don't settle for a quick review. Actually read every line of your notes 3 separate times. Once or twice will get you the big topics, but that third time will let you catch those tricky concepts or small details that might make or break the exam  -> Do the homeworks again. The homeworks are essentially sample exam questions. Do them again and then check your answers. Do this at least once, but as many times as you need to understand *all* the problems. Luckily you have the solutions and the work so you can catch any points where you don't understand some things.  -> If this class has any slides, read them over at least twice. Once will be enough to grab the big ideas, but twice or three times is what you need to catch all the details.  -> (Optional) If the class has readings (like books or textbook pages), you can try going over those, but in my opinion this will be too much for you to do. -> (Optional) Go to the TAs again if there's something you *really* don't get, they'll think of a way to make it easy for you to understand. NOTE: Make sure you to give yourself enough time. This process will take about three days to finish if you do one "run through" per day, which is what I recommend to let the information sink in.  Okay! Take a breath, that was a lot. This method is guaranteed to get you good grades. Why? Because this is not a "trick" or a "tactic" or some goofy learning technique that people try to use. This is just you legitimately learning all the material. 5 years from now, in a job interview, on the job, etc you will still remember a lot of what you learned, which will help you. I know this might sound like a lot of work, but trust me, I had a very active and enjoyable social life during college and still made this work. I also played a lot of music and videos games as well, so there was quite a bit of balance in my life. A little about me: I used this method for my undergrad degrees in chemical engineering and economics from Columbia University and my graduate degree in computer science from USC. I did very well at both these schools. Best of luck in college and I hope you take this method to heart. It served me well and it will serve anyone else who decides to use it.

In 2016, my first year of taking the IB Diploma ended with me obtaining an overall score of 33/45. That year was one filled with ‘littles’: Little sleep, little willpower to push on, and little clue on what the hell I was doing. One thing, however, wasn’t little: my intense hatred of the IB. (IB alumni all around the world, I bet you’re with me on this one!)  However, somewhere along the lines, something changed. In 2017, I graduated high school with an IB score of above 40. Imagine this: 40/45. A jump of over 7 points within a year. To put this in perspective, in 2016, I couldn’t even get into most courses in most of the universities in my own country. Today, almost all their doors are open. If I tried hard enough for the SATs, the Ivy Leagues like Harvard and Stanford wouldn’t be too distant a dream. Sure, you might argue that high school isn’t the equivalent of college, but boy did the IB Diploma Programme come close. If you aren’t aware of what the IBDP is, according to the official IB website, it’s a programme that aims to develop students to “have excellent breadth and depth of knowledge” that is comparable to that of a college major. So… how did I do it? How did I leap more than seven overall points in a single year? Handwrite all your notes. Or at least the vital points.As you handwrite your notes, your memory absorbs the information better. If you’d like to take an additional step, I suggest reading every point and synthesising the knowledge in your head, then writing the knowledge down by hand in your own words for maximum knowledge retention. While it takes more time for you to study this way, I guarantee that you will have a better understanding of the subject matter.  Schedule the heck out of your day.I was an Art student who was rushing to complete 6 pieces of work in a year. Then, there was a twenty page comparative Literature essay to be turned in three days from now. Oh, what about that Extended Essay draft? You get the gist - ‘free days’ are a nonexistent phrase in an IB student’s dictionary. In order to keep track of all my assignments, I became best friends with the calendar on my Mac and my journal. Every single day was scheduled to the hour, like a precisely orchestrated performance. Have enough sleep.8 hours of sleep every night in college? Ha, good joke! But, 6–7 hours every night while throwing in an occasional 8 is definitely doable. Throughout my 2 years while doing the IB, I never pulled an all-nighter. I didn’t believe in doing all-nighters because I believed they would affect your entire next day. Why “save” an additional six hours past midnight, only to have the next 24 hours affected with low productivity? Does this make sense to you? It doesn’t to me. Pomodoro TechniqueYou’ve probably heard this one before. Break your study time up into 25 minute blocks - 20 minutes of studying, followed by 5 minutes of break. During this break, get up and walk, get a glass of water, use the bathroom - do whatever you want, except continue to sit on the chair you’re sitting on while studying. By timing your study sessions, your brain gets incentivised to “work”, like how Journal consistentlyYou don’t have to journal every single day, but throwing in an entry or two every week is a great way to get you pumped and ready for that next study session. How might journaling relate to obtaining good grades? You see, journaling is an opportunity to reflect and maintain a dialogue with yourself. This way, you can actually see on paper where you went wrong, what processes you could have improved, and how you could create more productive study sessions in the future. Tracking your progress and improving your process is fundamental to actively make improvements in your life, be it within or beyond the academic sphere. Have an inspiring whyFor six months while doing the IB, I didn’t know why the hell I was doing what I was doing. I knew that I wanted to pursue something either business or creativity-related. How would atomic structures and periodicity help me in my future career?! Why the hell was I doing it? After months of pondering, I came to realise that my ‘Why’ was just to prove to myself that I could develop the resilience to power through activities that I didn’t like, and still excel in it. It was to develop an insane work ethic that would benefit me years after I completed the IB. Have a ‘Why’ greater than your present circumstances, and remind yourself that daily. Learn to love the process. Even if you hate what you’re doing.People tend to confuse and converge “love what you do” with “love the process”. The reality, however, is that these two phrases are actually very different. Loving the process means gaining satisfaction and feeling in control despite how challenging the situation might be. Because I was juggling my Art projects with all my other subjects and assignments, 12 hour workdays were the norm for me. Amidst these 12 hours, there were times when I was struggling with challenging math problems which I hated. I hated doing certain assignments or subjects during the day. Yet, looking back at each day and how I’ve managed to complete all that I’ve planned to do for the day, a wave of satisfaction would tide over me. That, my friend, is loving the process. I don’t believe that you would like every single thing you do every single day, but if the overall experience gives you immense satisfaction, you’re loving the process. And learning to love the process is more important. Find the right environment.During my days as an IB student, I would always head down to Singapore’s National library to study, even if it was 8pm and the sun had set hours earlier. On weekends, I’d get up at 7am just to make my way down so I could guarantee myself a seat. I had such an affinity towards that library despite it being an hour away from my house, because I loved the environment. Between the murmuring walls and amidst the calming rustle of flipping pages, entering my state of flow and concentration was such an easy task.  Looking back, it was insane how I managed to pull through my 2 years as an IB students. Yet, learning to hone my studying processes helped me to achieve the grades that I got in the end. If I can do it, so can you. All the best!

The most important thing you can do to ensure your success in college (which means learning things, not necessarily getting good grades--the two are NOT the same) is to learn how to learn.  For some reason, we spend years and years providing information on various subjects to children, but we never spend any time at all teaching them how to learn it.  We assume it is an inborn ability or something everyone just picks up as they go along, and it isn't.  Shockingly few people actually know how to efficiently get information into their brains in such a way that it will stick in such a way as so they will be able to retrieve it.   There is lots of research on cognition and learning and there are also a number of books written on the subject.  Google "learning how to learn" as a place to start. Learning how to learn is, by far, the most important thing you can do to facilitate success in college and beyond, but there are also a number of other habits and skills you also need to apply to get the most from the experience.  You have to want to learn, and you have to work at it.  The harder it is to learn things, generally the better you will learn them.  Go to class, every day, prepared (having done any readings and homework), and be an active participant.  Learning is NOT a passive process, and you can't expect to just sit and have someone pour learning into your ears and eyes.  The way to amass knowledge is to use it, relate it to other things, manipulate it and extend it.  Work on your classes every day.  Do not cram.  It might help a little on poorly designed exams, but it doesn't aid learning at all.  Your brain cannot process information like that.  Work with the way your brain works.  Study a bit and give your brain time to process.  By the way, you cannot multitask, so if you think you have to have music on or noise in the background to study, you are deluding yourself.  Your brain is a single-track processor and it cannot do two things (related things) at the same time.  Try to read and sing a song sometime.  You can do one or the other, but not both. Don't assume that, because you have had academic success in the past, that you already know how to learn.  You might just be really smart, and you've gotten good grades despite not having to work hard.  This is BAD for a new college student.  Just about killed me, because I had no idea how to study and learn when I got to college.  You can also have gotten good grades just by working really hard.  This also doesn't mean you know how to learn.  You might be working harder than you need to, and you will need to be more efficient with more difficult material. Do yourself a HUGE favor.  Do some reading on learning how to learn, believe what you read and apply it to your own situation.  It's a lot harder to change your ways than you might think.

Many good responses. Truthfully, though, what works for one person doesn't work for everyone. I was an undergrad for 8 years (thanks to my inability to choose a major) and I graduate with a 4.0. Here's what I did: 1) Always go to class. Pay attention to lecture - simply sitting in the room doesn't count. I figure if I learn what the professor is teaching rather than teaching it to myself later, that's time saved. It's also important to not just passively take notes, but to really listen to what the professor is saying. The more carefully you listen, the most questions you'll have, and now is the time to ask them - not the night before the homework is due. (Personally, I make it my goal to spot mistakes made by the professor - not to gleefully point them out, but it makes sure that I'm critically listening and not just recopying.) 2) Always do the homework, even if it isn't for a grade. If you have the solutions, don't cheat and look at them first - as everyone says, it'll be painfully obvious when the exam comes. I personally learn best having the solutions, because then I get instant feedback. To me it's useless to do an assignment, be confused about it, then have to wait two weeks to find out what I did wrong. However, I always try to solve the problem myself first, and only use the solutions if I'm really stuck. 3) Start studying at least a week before the exam. Cramming the night before miiiight get you through the test unscathed, but you definitely won't remember the information next semester when you need to use it again. I usually aim for completing my studying a couple days before the exam - you never know when something catastrophic might come up. For studying, it depends on your field - as an engineer, I would re-do end-of-the-chapter problems until I could do them very quickly, without having to think about them. Also: it's very dangerous to try and guess what will be on the exam. It's necessary sometimes because there simply isn't enough time to learn everything. But I've had classes where the majority of the class crashes and burns on an exam because they "didn't think the professor would ask that." Make sure you at least do a cursory review of everything, so you can scrape up some partial credit if you guessed wrong! It's a common misconception that all-nighters are a fundamental part of college. 8 years and I never once pulled an all-nighter! I like sleep. What's the point if you're a non-functioning zombie the next day? If you keep organized and manage your time well, there's no need. 4) Don't disregard introductory classes. I remember taking Calc I and thinking how silly it seemed; "when do I need to calculate the rate that water flows out of a bucket," but as an engineer I use calculus on a daily basis. What seems silly now is what builds the foundation for the complicated classes later. I think I'm actually really lucky in that I did the whole college thing sort of "backwards." I was most of the way through a degree in biomedical engineering, but starting wishing I had chosen mechanical engineering instead. I started working in a lab, reading an advanced textbook written by the advisor of said lab, and started minoring in ME. In this way, I saw the end-stage applications of ME in the lab, like the cool simulations you can run. I also saw how the things I was learning in Statics and Dynamics were critical, because I needed them in my research. I'm sure this backwards approach wouldn't work for everyone, but it's important to not lose the forest for the trees - everything you're working on now builds up to become cool, applied stuff later. I think it's also important to learn about what's going on in the field these days. The boring introductory classes won't seem so boring if you're excited about what awesome stuff you'll be able to do in a few years.  A lot of people talk about forming study groups, but I have never once studied with someone else. I prefer to work on my own, though I know plenty of people who see the value in collaboration. I also never focused on attending office hours - if I had a specific question, sure, but I didn't make a point to always attend. Again, everyone's different!

Here’s my number 1, super-secret, guaranteed-to-work-or-your-money-back piece of advice for getting good grades. Are you ready for it? Brace yourself, because it might just blow your mind… Take classes you actually enjoy. I know… sounds simple, doesn’t it. Almost too simple, right? But, after teaching college classes for over a decade, I’m 100% positive very few students realize this. In other words, a student might love poetry, but majors in some type of engineering because he feels like that’s the only way to get a job. Or a student would rather be studying computer science but her parents want her to be a doctor, so she’s busy taking biology and anatomy classes she loathes. News flash: when you hate your classes, it’s hard to do well in them. The reason you’ll have trouble doing well in classes you hate is underscored by all the other answers to this question. Specifically, do you see how they tend to focus on tactics like studying more, prioritizing work, and other kinds of “work harder” tasks? Well, working harder in a class is orders of magnitude more difficult when you hate it. Just as importantly, taking classes you hate doesn’t just impact your “challenging” classes. In fact, working harder in classes you don’t like often gives you better grades in them, but it usually comes at the expense of your grades in classes you truly love. For example, I’m often forced to give bad grades to wonderful students who love my classes because they skipped my classes too often or didn’t do their homework assignments in order to finish work for other classes they hated but considered “more important.” Mind you, I’m not insulted when students prioritize other classes over mine. But, for the students who enjoy my classes more, I usually feel terrible for them because they can’t see the proverbial “forest through the trees.” They’re so focused on getting better grades in the classes they hate that they can’t see all the opportunities for them in the classes they love. Agree with me? Think my answer is ridiculous? Read more about my experiences teaching entrepreneurship, and share your thoughts.

In addition to Cory A. Martin's advice to just show up and do your work, the following will make your professor not curse your name (which will be critically important when grading your assignments and/or deciding if we should give you the last 3 points you need to bump up your grade one level). Read the syllabus. Read it again. If you have a question, read the syllabus. If you still have a question, read the syllabus again. If you really are stumped and want to email the professor: Make sure your subject line is succinct about what kind of question you have. "Question regarding research assignment for CRIJ 1301 M/W 10:00-11:20 A.M." is best. "IMPORTANT!!!!!!!!!!!" is a fast way to get deleted unread. Even if you already did so in the subject line, identify specifically which class you are in and who you are by name as it appears on your school records. "I'm in your class" doesn't help. I teach several classes. I don't know who Bubba is; I have 5 Roberts in one class alone, and then I have various names starting with a B. Address me by my title. You have not earned the privilege of calling me by my first name or some other nickname, unless I specifically tell you otherwise (and I won't until maybe after you graduate). Succinctly explain your problem. Include the steps you took to try to solve the problem on your own. Wait patiently for a response. It may takes us a few days to sort out how best to help you, or even to have enough time to draft that email. Don't send multiple emails every few minutes asking "Did you get my e-mail?" Likewise, don't ask us at 8 AM if we saw the email you sent last night, especially if it is a Monday morning. Now that we have handled the syllabus... Textbooks: get them (buy, rent, borrow, whatever). The one we have listed in the syllabus is the one we want. You might be able to get away with an older edition. Maybe. Sometimes the changes are minimal. Sometimes they are substantial. Any differences are your responsibility, not mine. Don't ask "Do we really need the textbook?" Yes, you need the textbook, I wouldn't list it as required otherwise. No, I don't get rich off of these, even if I did write the book. Textbook authors see very little of the price of a textbook. Now that you have the textbook(s), read them. Study them. Come to class prepared to join in a discussion on the assigned chapters. Come to class with questions about what you read. Schedules and Deadlines:Follow them. Don't email me and ask if you missed anything yesterday, or if you will miss anything important if you leave for holiday early. Don't ask if you can turn in something late: if I allow it, it will be in my syllabus, along with how I will handle late work in different circumstances (I'll work with someone who was hit by a bus on the way to class, but if you forgot because you were stoned I have nothing for you). Get a planner. A physical one that you have to physically write it. It will help your remember better, and you can use it to keep track of all of your deadlines in all of your classes. Written work:Follow the directions. Use proper spelling and grammar, even if you aren't in English class. Especially if you aren't in English class. Don't ignore spellcheck. Use proper sources. If we say Wikipedia is a nogo, then don't even try it. We can tell when you copy/paste something, even if you don't cite your source. We're also wise to most other shenanigans you can do to get around the requirements. We've been doing this much longer than you have. General:Don't lie. Don't cry. Don't have your helicopter parents step in when you cry. Take responsibility for yourself like a grown, mature adult. ****All of these combined will help make you be the kind of student who doesn't make a professor cringe when they see your name. When we pick up your research paper to grade it, you want us to think "Oh, this is Bubba's, this should be good!" instead of "Oh, this is Bubba's, I'm going to need some whiskey first...". With something as subjective as your grade on the line, you want us to be in as happy a mood as possible when your name comes up.

Others have some excellent suggestions.  Here are mine: Maintain a regular study routine in every class.  Multiple short stints of studying per week are much more effective than are longer bursts of studying at less frequent intervals.  Neuroscience researchers now believe the primary biochemical basis of memory is something called long-term potentiation: when a synapse connecting neurons is used more frequently, it gets stronger.  Exercise the relevant neurons many times a week and you'll form such strong memories that you don't need to do much studying during finals week.Some people find study groups helpful, but some don't.  But if you do join a study group, work all the problems yourself before each meeting of your group, for several reasons.  First, only by working problems without assistance can you avoid fooling yourself into thinking you understand the problems better than you really do.  Second, if you make a serious effort before your study group meeting, then you will know where you got stuck and therefore be able to make more effective use of your time in the group meeting.  Third, if you have made a serious effort before your study group meeting, then you will be better prepared to help other group members with their difficulties.  Fourth, if you have worked all the problems before each study group meeting, you'll soon be able to tell whether the others have done so (and if the others in your study group regularly fail to work problems on their own, you should find a different study group).I strongly agree you should go to office hours regularly, not only the Professor's office hours but also the office hours of your T.A.  I was a T.A. myself when I was a graduate student, and nothing frustrated me more than students who only started asking me for help near the end of the semester when it was often too late to salvage their situation.  Come early and come frequently.  But also come prepared, just like what I said above about study groups.Read each assigned chapter in the book at least twice.  The bare minimum is one reading within the 48 hours preceding the class for which that chapter is assigned, and one reading within the 48 hours following the class in which that chapter is covered.  Some authors also advise taking notes while doing the assigned reading and taking those notes to class, so that in class you only have to write down the differences between what the textbook says and how your instructor handles the content.  But frankly I was a very poor note-taker and I did pretty well!  My notebooks mostly resembled XKCD comics, actually.  But although I didn't take very good notes, what I did right was more important: I read the textbook frequently and I worked the assigned problems.  If you always arrive at class ready to compare how your teacher looks at the subject with how somebody else covers the same material then you will get much more out of your time in the classroom.During Reading Period and Finals week, relax.  If you already know the material, then a quick skim of the textbook to refresh your memory will be more than sufficient.  If you do not already know the material by now, desperate attempts to catch up will only make you tired and even more stressed-out.  The single most important thing you can do during Finals Week is get plenty of sleep, and also get outside a lot!  If you have followed points 1 through 4 above, then you should have plenty of time to sleep and exercise during Finals Week.  I usually found Finals Week the least stressful part of the semester because I had plenty of time to just wander around campus.

A2A Your question makes me want to find a way on Quora to simply link to answers already given. But, here goes. First realize that pursuing good grades and developing deep understanding of the material are often two different things. Others will probably repeat for you all of the standard answers about attendance and proper study methods and habits. Those are good. But, you need to realize this truth. Getting good grades is based on determining what the instructor wants and giving it to them. There should be a syllabus which tells you how the course points are organized and how to obtain them. You get good grades by doing those things the way the professor wants and collecting the points. I had an undergrad professor for basic geology and astronomy who hated teaching lower level courses. His quizzes were worth very few points. Getting A’s on his midterm and final equaled an A in the course. So, you went to class and listened, read the book, and got whatever extra points you could on the quizzes in case you needed them for the big exams. Then he would do a review day before the exams and tell you everything that was on the tests. I got A’s in his course by taking rapid notes on his reviews, memorizing everything he said to know, and giving it back to him on exams. His courses helped me finish my undergrad program with straight A’s. But, I learned very little from him and later had to return to studying the subjects on my own when I encountered things I wanted to know and understand. I had an excellent professor who based grades on papers. In those papers he expected to see that you had read and understood the research, had contemplated it, and could clearly articulate your reasoning and conclusions. He did NOT require your answers to match his answers. He expected you to demonstrate clear understanding of the readings and your ability to write quality explanations of what you learned. If you gave him that, you earned A’s. I learned a great deal from him. I had a professor in my Masters who fooled me for one exam, and I had to play catch up to get my A by the end of the term. His grades were based on essay exams. It was an issues class. In discussions, he usually took a liberal position in opposition to the students who were mostly conservative at that particular school. On the first exam, I gave clear answers citing the source materials to back the views he had argued in class. I got an OK grade, but not what I wanted. It took one test to figure out that he was arguing a side he did not believe in discussions to force people to get into the materials and think. But in the end, he expected to see conservative conclusions. On the remaining exams, I gave him what he wanted and earned my A. I also learned from him, even though I did not agree with his approach or many of his conclusions based on the readings he selected. You get high marks by giving the grader what they want to see. Learning and retaining knowledge and understanding are sometimes a very different and more difficult (and rewarding!) game.

I had a graduate student who, as an undergrad at Cornell, had more A+ grades than As -- about 15. Once I asked him how he did that. "I use tricks" he said. They all seemed so obvious when he told me, that I'm not sure I can recall all of them. Below I'll mix in what he said with some of the things I observed in other great students. He said he always read the assignment before the lecture, not after. Do that, and you know what to pay most attention to. You can ask questions about things you didn't understand. You can't ask a book questions, but you can ask a professor. Moreover, your professor will be impressed that you ask the best questions. Remarkably, it takes no longer to read all the material before class than after class. Visit the professor during office hours. Some professors will just try to intimidate you into not coming so often; ignore them. Some will be delighted to have visitors. It is a great opportunity to interact with a very smart and very knowledgeable person. Don't try to learn what you think is important, but try to learn what you think the professor thinks is most important. That's really why the professors are there; they have enormously more experience in the subject, and know what is really important. You'll discover you do much better on exams. Find other students to study with. College is not a place to try to prove you are better than everyone else; it is a place where, among other things, you can learn how to work well with other people. Try throwing good questions at your friends. It turns out that thinking of good questions gets you very far. Don't be surprised if some of the questions turn out to be the same ones the professor asks. Go to lecture and, particularly if it is boring, try to figure out why the material is actually fascinating. All those courses are there because someone thinks it is important, even if your current professor doesn't. Once you become interested in the material, it will be easy to learn; in fact, it will be hard to forget. Recognize that not all the material is equally important. See if you can identify that. Think hard about the important stuff. Take this to be your top homework design: there is a person who has limited time, not really enough, to learn some material. What is the best way to approach that? Pretend that that question is a homework exercise, and write a page. Then follow your own suggestions.

Buy enough pencils, erasers or any type of stationery.Pay Attention and Attend classes:ALWAYS pay attention in class. If you never pay attention, you’ll never know any information that may be included in future tests or exams. If you are the type of person who forgets easily, this is fine. The purpose of binders is to take notes and revise the notes when you are studyingAnother way is to attend classes. By attending classes, you can pay attention and gain new information. I have been a Teaching Assistant in one of the top engineering schools in the United States for quite some time and would like to share my experiences about how you can increase your chances of getting good grades: Never miss lecture.My adviser compiled a set of statistics showing how the grades of the students showed a high positive correlation with the number of lectures attended. Sure, showing up in class in spite of a life threatening medical emergency is not the best of ideas, but never skip lecture because you have to study for another test. The number of hours that you need to put in in order to make up for the missed lecture is far more than what you had initially bargained for. Pay attention during lecture.Again, to quote my adviser, "The most important part of the class is not on the slides." Pay attention to the side information that the professor is bringing to the table. He might mention a seemingly short sentence on an important concept, which might prove to be useful to solve an important question on the midterm or crack a job interview. If they have set certain pre-lecture or pre-lab reading assignments, make sure you read those. The professors are doing this job for many many years, respect their intelligence and experience.  Make the best of office hours.Most of the professors and TAs have a reasonable number of office hours per week. Ask them questions not only on the materials covered in the homework due this week but also overall on the overall course. In fact, the top students I have taught asked questions to understand the concepts more deeply rather than, "Hey Miss TA, how do I solve Problem 3 b)?". I have had students drop by and chat with me about the graduate school application process, the PhD experience and which research areas are hot topics etc. I was more than happy to give them my two cents. Plan your coursework.Make sure you set up an appointment with your graduate adviser and chalk out the coursework path not only for the current semester but also for the future semesters. Read reviews on ratemyprofessor or other websites in order to decide the professors with whom you want to take the courses. Do not leave difficult courses till your senior year. That year is spent mostly in applying and interviewing for jobs, appearing for GRE and the graduate school application process. I myself barely got to study during my senior year and it dragged my GPA down to some extent.  Get your basics right.At least in engineering, I see that many of the students do not have the required mathematical skills for certain classes. Pay attention to your calculus, complex analysis, real analysis, linear algebra classes. Having a solid foundation translates to not having to waste time on these topics when you take the advanced upper division classes. In your senior year Digital Signal Processing course, it would be no fun to spend half of the time revising polar representation of complex numbers. Eat the frog.You might hate a certain course because a) The professor is bad b) The course is not interesting c) Both a) and b). In spite of that, this course may be a core requirement in your program. Given these circumstances, it is best to silently bear with the pain for one semester and get done with it. Complaining does not help. Life is never a bed of roses. Study smart.First read the materials and then start doing the homework instead of the other way round. It saves a lot of time. Be comfortable with the types of questions asked in exams by looking at exams from previous years. Form study groups with similar minded students, especially for the tough courses. I have myself benefitted a lot from studying in groups. Prepare for tests in advance.The top students never pull out all-nighters just the day before the midterm or the final. Have a good night's sleep. Do not rush to the professor's of the TA's office hours < 12 hours before the exam to learn important concepts. This only results in you forgetting what you already know. Be good at taking tests. Learn to manage your time well after you see the questions in the exam. Avoid spending too much of time on one problem.  Lastly, don't be a d***.The teaching team is NOT your babysitter. When you walk in through the office door of the professor or the TA, leave your sense of entitlement behind. Just because you are paying tuition, does not mean that the teaching staff is at your beck and call. They are only there to help you find the solutions to the assignments, they won't do your homework for you. Never start the homework during the TA's office hours, it sends out really bad vibes. I have seen some students having serious attitude problems that would have got them fired from their company on the very first day. TL;DR: Study hard and well in advance.

By making the required effort. When I was studying, my aim was always to get average grade. Didn't care much about getting good grades. I was lazy or more busy with my own interests. My own interests was software programming and microprocessors (I was studying to become electrical engineer but these software programming/microprocessors was not part of my course) When I was waiting for the interview with the professor for dissertation, I heard he was speaking to PhD student. Professor asked the student to do something practical but student was reluctant and insisted that the task was beyond his capabilities etc. I went in to the professor's office next. He asked about what I would like to do. I said I wanted to write 100 pages thesis about communication protocols (which is kind of linked with electrical engineering). Professor's eye lit up. He asked if I knew about programming etc. I couldn't say no even though something inside me said, just lie, don't let him know you know these. I told the truth and when I was going out from the office, my task was to:  develop electronic card (circuit) with a microprocessor+ software which runs on windows 98 (yes it was in the last century) to control the electronics.  Aim was: electronic card would be connected to the PC, user would send commands from the PC to the card and this commands would be sent to remote location over internet. Another electronic card receives the signal and controls the equipment there.  I completed the project, it worked. I handed over the documentation to professor for his review. And then just asked about the grade. He answered, write here whatever you want. I was honored, smiled and wrote A+ as anyone else would do.  I think it was the only A+ I had.

Good is relative. Some colleges are more competitive than other. Lot will depend on you current standing (study approach as well as performance) and gap you want to fill with what is consider as good in your academic setting. At the very minimal level you have to master & commit yourself to basic good study habits which includes: a) Showing up: in classroom, in labs, in library, in project meetings. This is 50% of the work. Your lizard brain will find million reason to bunk just 'one' lecture, one meeting, one more session. Learn to quite or ignore lizard brain. b) Doing you homework: Assignments are big part of you grades. Take help, work with a team, join a study group. Do whatever it take to submit your assignments on time. c) Finding right peer group: Spend more time with people who also wants get good grades and who are committed to help eahc other for this shared goal. Peer pressure works both ways. Being part of a competitive yet supportive group will inspire you to work hard & stay focused. Same way wrong kind of peer pressure can be a big distraction. Find your tribe. Align your environment with your future goals. d) Answering 'whys' often: Mindless slogging for grades is not sustainable. Grades are mean to an end. Trying to get good grades just to impress society or parents may not be that inspiring. Right reasons are personal, meaningful and should justify all the sacrifices. Spend some time into introspection. Meet & talk to successful people who inspires you. Volunteer for non-academic work so that you can connect academic understanding with real life problems. That will keep you sane in blind grade race. e) Seeking help. Teenage is turbulent age. Lots of changes inside mind & body. Do not shy away from seeking help. Especially for thing that you have little control on. F) Identifying & eliminating distraction. We fail to realize the commutative impact small distinction (email, calls, gossip) have on our attention span and hence productivity. Sometime identifying a unproductive task can be difficult. Like spending hours on Quora may look productive but it may not be. Track you time. Have a close look at your calendar and understand how productively you are spend your time. All these suggestions look quite obvious (or innocuous) but you will surprised to see how fews tudents are able to commit themself to such a minimal 'get good grade' program. OptimizationOnce you have acquire mastery on above basic you can look for next level optimizations. You can work on personal productivity i.e. getting more thing done in same time. Hunt for good education hacks specific to your learning style, academic needs and your environment. Interview top performers. Make study checklist and review it before every exam or semester. Spend more time with Profs. Also readDavid Koh's answer to Studies and Studying: How do top students study? Study Hacks - Decoding Patterns of Success - Cal NewportHow do top students study?

You get “good grades in college” like you get everything else—a. Someone gives them to youb. You steal (cheat) for themc. You work for them Think about it…all you have and all you will ever have comes by one of these three ways: ….it is given…you steal it…you work for it It may be that somewhere, sometime, people will “give” to you, such as your parents, family, or close friends. Maybe someone will give you something that they no longer want it. Perhaps they will throw it away, discard it. But if yougo through life “expecting” gifts, you are very likely to be disappointed most of the times. You may have heard people say, “there is no free lunch.” Of course, most of the world—in most situations—will frown on stealing. “What is thine-is mine” is not an acceptable outlook. Cheating is a way to get good grades. I have known students who worked hard to cheat, harder than they would have if they had worked (studied). When we cheat to get good grades, we cheat ourselves not only out of what we would have learned, but from we would have learned from what we learned. Sometimes what we learn is not as important as what we WILL learn as a result of having learned. Knowledge builds upon other knowledge. Things we learn may not seem to have immediate value, but overtime that “learning” will enable you to learn something else. Not all work is fun. Working for good grades is not usually fun. I have had students say “I enjoyed your class” or “it’s been fun.” I always wonder about that because learning is sometimes hard. Learning is also disturbing, especially when we learn that we were wrong. So, in short, just like anything else—you will place a higher value on it, IF you work for it. What do you think? Michael
