I can tell you how I did it. First, and as others have said, read the assignment before lecture. It never occurred to me to do it the other way round, so I didn’t know before reading other answers here that this was a “thing.” In any case, if you’re not already doing the reading before lecture, you should start. In fact, at least if you’re majoring in philosophy, you should read the assignment twice – first just to get a sense of what’s being argued for, and then to evaluate it. In lecture, pay very close attention and take very schematic notes. Immediately after lecture write out a fuller account of what you learned, together with your own comments, questions, and indications of things that are not fully clear to you. Don’t just outline or list bullet points – indicate the development of the idea or argument and what motivates it, what’s at stake. The point of doing this is not to have something on paper to review later, though that can be helpful. The point is that if you do this you’ll find that you remember everything effortlessly. Cultivate a group of the smartest people you can find and discuss the topics you’re studying with them, both formally and informally. I did this without really thinking about it, but if it’s not happening in your case devote some conscious effort to it. It’s less important that your interlocutors are in the specific class you’re taking than that they’re intelligent and passionate about whatever they’re doing. My own circle of friends in college included artists, physicists, English, Comp Lit and History majors, social science and psychology types, and even an engineer or two. I learned from all of them. Of course, you should talk with people who know the subject you’re studying, but there’s value in trying to explain a problem to someone who knows nothing about it, in part because you’ll quickly identify the gaps in your knowledge. (I felt I learned a tremendous amount as a student, but it was almost nothing compared to how much I learned when I started to teach.) Looking back, some of the people I got the most from when I was an undergraduate were grad students. The beginning ones aren’t much older than you, but for obvious reasons they’re at least a little ahead of you without being as intimidating as a professor can be. You’ll meet them in your discussion sections, but you’ll find that many are also in the social networks of other undergraduates you’ll be getting to know. (Of course, this bit of advice applies only to those studying at a research university.) Speaking of professors, take advantage of their office hours. You’ll find a wide range of personalities: some will be nurturing, others will just shoot holes in whatever you have to say. Don’t take it personally; you can benefit from either approach. What if you’re stuck in a class with a prof who just doesn’t seem that interested in what he or she is doing? Don’t waste time complaining about it, to others or to yourself. He or she is probably having a bad month or semester or year. Find another way into the subject – a good discussion section sometimes saves an otherwise dreary course. I distinctly remember one particular course in which the teaching assistant was far more effective than the professor – and the prof was actually very good.

Attend every class: If you want good grades in college, you must attend every class, not almost every class. The importance of regular class attendance cannot be overemphasized. When you miss classes, you miss lectures, notes, discussions, explanations, and assignments. Do not think that missing a class won’t make a difference. You cannot make up what you miss. Be organized:o   Use a student planner: take this to each class and record all assignments. Also use your planner to keep track of tests and quizzes, activities and appointments.o   Break down assignments: large assignments are more manageable if you break them down into smaller parts. Completing these smaller portions over a longer period of time will allow you more time to focus Manage your time well: with good time management, you have more free time, less stress and a feeling that you are in control.Don’t overextend yourselfSchedule 90 minute study sessions: set a specific time to get your studying done and make sure you will not be interrupted. During these study sessions, don’t do anything else but study!Take Good Notes: tests usually cover material that the instructor has presented in class. Therefore, it is important to have good class notes.o   Be an active listener: when your actively listening, your not just hearing the words, but you are also thinking about and trying to understand the information being presented.o   Taking notes can help you pay attention and stay focused.o   Recognize important information: anything the instructor writes on the board is important. In your notes, underline or star the most important information so you can pay special attention to it when studying. Know How to Read a Textbook: Knowing how to scan, read and review will make it much easier for you to understand and remember what you read.o   Scan: scanning gives you a quick overview of the material you’re going to be reading. To scan, read the title, subtitle, and everything in bold and italic print. Look at the pictures, captions, charts, graphs, and read the introduction, the summary and the review questions.o   Read: when your reading has a purpose, you have a reason to stay focused and your comprehension improves.o   Review: to review, first ask yourself ‘what is the main idea’ and then go back to the beginning and go through the same process you did when you scanned the material. This time, as you scan restate the main idea of each passage using your own words. Study Smart: students who study smart find themselves spending less time of studying and still getting better grades.o   Find a good place to study: make sure the area is free of distractions.

When I came to study at Princeton University, I soon realized that studying hard was not sufficient to achieve the best grades. Instead, I had to discover and develop a habit of studying intelligently. For me, this meant moving away from brute-force memorization. I couldn’t simply memorize math formulas and expect to get an A on the final. My study strategies varied by subject, but I discovered some thematic strategies. Split up your time into general (20%) and specific (80%) studies. 20% should be spent on general studies for breadth (e.g., skimming the textbook or building broad study guides). The other 80% should go towards acute reinforcement of the specific topics where you fail (e.g., narrow classes of math problems).Practice and self-evaluation is critically important. This concept is even more important in technical fields like mathematics, physics or computer science. Memorizing concepts will not get you very far if you don’t practice problem solving which involves applying these concepts. This means working through as many practice exams as you can. If there are none available, ask the professor for past exams to use as study material or make your own practice quizzes.During timed exams, focus on packing your essay responses with information and analysis — don’t worry about the prose or poetry. The graders are probably tired graduate students looking for key points which answer the question. Don’t waste time adding literary flourishes. Be elegant in your writing by being concise and clear. Also, remember that while information is important, analysis of the information is equally important.From personal experience, these three core strategies are very effective. They have helped me achieve academic success at Princeton in a broad range of subjects (ranging from mathematics and computer science to English and Near Eastern studies). During my junior year, I was awarded the Shapiro Prize for academic excellence (top 3% in my class).

I distinctly remember entering University as naïve as a first generation university student could be. I harbored doubts about how many modules I was going to pass or even the lack of sleep that I was going to encounter. Needless to say that over the four years that I had spent at University, I began to realize just how unfounded all of my doubts were. Over time and through observing some of the most impressive students, I began to realize that they had all adopted certain strategies that enabled them to become top students as well as leaders and agents of change. Once I had started implementing these strategies, I found myself performing at an exceptional level not just within the classroom, but also outside of the classroom, through the various activities that I had been involved in. I aim to share these strategies with you and hopefully help you achieve all of the goals that you had set out for yourself at university. 1. Find your passion and study itThis point may seem rudimentary and somewhat cliché, yet so few people really study what they are passionate about. There are a lot of reasons for this for example; family pressures, bursary opportunities and degrees that promise a lucrative pay check. However, you need to push against these forces and follow your passion relentlessly.I was fortunate enough to have found my passion for Economics at a young age. Economics appealed to me because it encompassed my passion for entrepreneurship, mathematics, politics and psychology. I found myself being so engrossed by all of the topics that I had covered in class that I found myself thinking about them at a much higher level and applying what I was learning to various real world scenarios. Instead of studying being a chore, I found it to be quite pleasurable. I woke up every day extremely excited about what I was going to learn and achieve next. 2. Believe in YourselfThis point is equally important and I cannot stress it enough. Believing in what you are doing and saying is a fundamental part of success. I found that by doing what I loved and succeeding in it my self-belief was vastly improved. It was this self-belief that I had used within other areas within my life which helped me stand out as a leader and change agent. Belief isn’t something that someone is born with. Rather, it is something that needs to be cultivated and reinforced on a daily basis. Self-belief can be, writing your goals on your wall, befriending confident people or even listening to rap music. Believe you can and you’re already halfway there. 3. Understand opportunity costThe opportunity cost of an activity is the cost of the best foregone opportunity. To elaborate on this topic further, let me use a hypothetical example. If I were to skip my Calculus class on a Friday at 7:30am in order to sleep for an extra half an hour, the opportunity cost of sleeping that extra half an hour is two percentage points on my final Calculus mark. The relevance of opportunity cost is that it allows you to understand that every decision you make has an equivalent cost. Therefore, by understanding that, you are able to approach the decisions you make on a daily basis in a more mature way and one that maximizes your limited time and ensures that you’re able to adequately prioritise your daily tasks and activities. You’ll have a clear grasp of the concept, there is a time and a place for everything and in a world with an array of temptations, that you’re able to make the best decision. If they have a meeting with a multi-millionaire, the opportunity cost of not meeting him would be one percentage point? What would you do?The best students understand that there is a time and a place for everything. They understand the concept of opportunity cost and it underpins their daily decisions. 4. Comparative Advantage Comparative advantage is another important concept that needs to be understood by all. Basically what it means is that, if there are two people who provide two different services, the person who is more efficient, has a comparative advantage in providing that service. By leveraging off one another, they can both benefit.When you are studying and trying to balance various extra mural activities, your time will be severely constrained. The best students are able to acknowledge their strengths and weaknesses respectively and use comparative advantage in order to save time and improve understanding of certain concepts. Moreover, it will improve your communication skills which will prove invaluable when you are in a position to explain complex concepts.An example of the application of this concept is: Assume that you’re very good at Economics and can study a chapter in 1 hour and take 3 hours to complete a chapter of Calculus. Moreover, assume you have a friend who can do a chapter of Calculus in 1 hour and Economics in 3. Therefore, it would take you and your friend 4 hours to cover two topics. By understanding comparative advantage however, you can save an hour by studying the module at which you are better in and asking your friend to explain Calculus to you and vice versa.Throughout my four years at university, my friends and I continuously applied this principle to great avail. Ignore this concept at your own peril. 5. 80/20 principleThe 80/20 principle was first conceptualized by Vilfredo Pareto in 1896. This principle states that 80 percent of the effects can be achieved by doing 20 percent of the causes. Put another way, 80% of the results can be generated by 20% of the work.The best students have either willingly or unwillingly applied this rule to their studies and life in general. They’ve used Pareto’s principle by understanding that 80% of the results can be achieved by 20% of the work. They understand that a lot of the groundwork is done in the classroom, their interactions with their professors, homework and practicals.They understand the importance of group studying, getting advice from students who have done the module before and practicing past papers.It is important to note that every module or task that you will take at university is different. That said, there is still a system that needs to be understood in order for you to make the most of the principle. Why study the whole textbook when only 20% of it is relevant? Understand what is expected of you, ask for advice and use the system to your advantage. By doing this, you’ll have a lot more time to enjoy your university career. 6. Network, Network, Network…Networking is something to be taken very seriously. You are an average of the 5 people you spend the most time with.Over time, I had noticed that people tend to associate with those who have similar interests to theirs. The best students however, understand that they need to have a diverse group of friends. By this I mean, they understand what it means to network with intelligent students, entrepreneurs, artists and leaders. They understand the value that these networks can bring and the wealth of ideas that can come through interactions with these people.Choose your friends wisely. Acknowledge the importance of your networks. I was fortunate enough to have a vast network that I still keep in touch with today. I have learnt and developed a great deal through my interactions with all of these people. Moreover, they have enabled me to have access to various opportunities and ideas that I would never have known about had I not made a concerted effort to develop and maintain my friendships. 7. DO NOT JUST STUDY… Get involved in activities and societies that interest youIt bothers me when people continuously complain about being so swamped with their studies that they don’t have time to do anything else. One can no longer distinguish themselves by getting good grades anymore. Companies and scholarships are now looking for people who not only achieved academically but those who were involved in social outreach and leadership initiatives. They are looking for the complete individual. I suggest that you continuously get involved in societies and initiatives that interest you. The benefits of this strategy includes; developing a diverse network, learning new skills, CV building and fully exploring the vast range of opportunities that your university presents you with. In conclusion, remember that you are extremely privileged to be able to go to university and further your studies. Take this seriously. You owe it to yourself and your country to use this opportunity in the best possible way. Learn as much as you can and continuously strive to expand your experiences. When you become successful, do not forget to share it with the people who are not as fortunate as you. Our world needs ambitious and skilled young people who take initiative in order to help take us to where we could and should be.

Good grades is all about focusing on what the professor or tutor is discussing in classroom. No teacher or professor in this world will ever test their pupils on material that hasn’t been discussed in classroom. Attend lectures and pay attention. Do your homework and grades will come. Now, all is not fine and dandy all the time, because in real world plans will fail. And though grades will suffer, you’ll learn some important lessons for the rest of your life, which are much more important than grades. It happened to me during my Master’s program. I had all A+ grades until course in Software Architecture, one of the exams was about designing architecture for some requirements. The question was open ended and I went nuts focusing more on non-functional properties of the system over functional properties. That costed me my A and I’ll remember to this day where the first focus needs to be when thinking of practical software architecture. The second was Embedded Systems course. While most exams were straightforward, one of the major assignments took much time and it was the last quarter so search was jobs was intense. I wanted to not have gap after graduation. That single assignment was incomplete and I could’ve gotten a worse grade if I didn’t engage my instructor and ask for another assignment or work to make up. Yes, it took burning some midnight hours and stress but at least I was left with a B+. So, next couple lessons are, never ease on even a single assignment. Do the best every time. And if things go south be honest with instructor and ask for work to make up for lost chance at excellence. Any reasonable instructor is generally obliging. If not, tough luck.

Some good advice offered by other Quorans here already so I’ll chip in 2 cents for you, and try to offer you a unique angle; Lifting your academic skill set to high grades is likely to take a fair bit of time. Make no mistake, with some small improvements in how efficent you are each day in your study you can certainly expect to see a quick rise in your grades in any assessment in the weeks to follow. Rather, its just true too - and knowing a little something about this given I’ve written half a dozen eBooks in this field (linked below) - it is important for students to recognise if seeking to go from a D or C grade to A+ that improving your overall academic ability shall take time. Certainly, a student shouldn’t get disencouraged by that - its like how an athlete training for the Rio Olympics took many training sessions of incremental gains to get there - rather may this just guard against a good guy or girl trying one week to lift their grades, the next week finding on exams they were the same, and then going ‘Oh this is hopeless, I’ll never get great grades’. Concerning specific advice, I would say (alongside perhaps having a look over my eBook to build up these skills in-depth) a focus on efficency and output over time alone is a solid guiding star for lifting your grades. For example, while it may sound impressive if one student studies for 12 hours in the library, if that time is spent just passively reading a textbook a student who studies for only 4 - but does so by intently and proactively seeking to find out what they don’t know, learn it, and then master it - shall always see the better results returned to them at semester’s end. So, may you make it your aim to be that student, and certainly I wish you luck in getting there!:) Ed Phillip Journalist and Author Read more from Ed in 60 Steps to College Success: from First Year to Final Year, Essays, Exams and More! available from Amazon Kindle (download for free until May 9 2017)

General tips: If you have to take a sequence of classes, schedule them immediately after one another. This may be obvious to most, but it wasn’t for me. It hurt me in German. Learn to take notes well. Don’t use complete sentences. Get the main idea down. Doodle. Leave some white space so you can go over them later and expand them while they are fresh on your mind. Have a notebook with pockets for those handouts and keep them with that lecture’s notes! Read the first chapter of all your textbooks before the first day of class. I did this and it helped me. Sit down the middle or in the first row or two. I have ADD and this helped me pay attention better. Keep your syllabus handy [that sheet with the class outline your professor gives the first class] and do all reading and assignments on time. Read the material before the lecture. Write down any questions you have and ask them. Make sure you pay special attention during the lecture. Any topic discussed will definitely be on tests! Don’t put off starting projects and papers. If your class requires a lab and it’s optional, treat it as vital! I didn’t in German class and barely passed. I did in College Algebra and it saved me! Take advantage of labs and tutoring. If you’re religious, pray and do some scripture study before studying anything when you start your study sessions. You’ll make a grade higher! Read your notes after class daily. Don’t cram or you won’t remember your material after class is over. This is vital if you have subject sequences! Realize that there are different ways to study different subjects. For Math, you learn by doing problems. Do more problems than are assigned. If you are weak in math, get some extra books and do those problems, or ask for extra problems. You won’t understand it until you have done x of that type of problem, and x = different for everybody! Foreign languages are learned by listening to those tapes and speaking. Don’t just concentrate on the written part. You have to write and speak to pass. Listen and repeat. Singing is also learned by singing. Practice practice practice for any music class. For music appreciation. listen to the types of music you are studying. English is learned by writing, especially essays. Remember this formula for essays: Write one paragraph on your main statement. Include at least 3–5 points supporting your main statement [odd numbers are better]. One sentence per point. Last sentence should restate your main statement. Write one paragraph on each of your points. Be convincing! Each paragraph should be 4–5 sentences. Write your closing paragraph and re-emphasize your points. Phrase them differently. Read your essay. Do you convince yourself of what you’re trying to say? If not, rewrite or pick another topic to argue. History is learned by memorizing facts and dates. Don’t ever think dates are not important. Science is best learned in a study group. If no one is passing around a sign-up sheet for a group when you walk in the first day, pass one of your own around with Name, Preferred Meet Day/Time, and Contact Info across the top. Be sure and put yours first line and identify yourself as leader. If someone else is starting a group and you find out, offer to consolidate the groups. You learn a lot of facts but in science, you are expected to come up with ideas of your own to share. It is a lot harder to pass a science course without a study group to bounce ideas off of and quiz each other. I’ve done it both ways. If you’re still in high school, practice these techniques now! I moved at half-year my senior year and had to do triple homework for 3 weeks to graduate early. Even that was not the amount of work I did my first quarter in college! College may feel overwhelming at first, but don’t give up. Your body and mind will adjust after just a few weeks! It is overwhelmingly satisfying to see how much you can actually make your mind and body do. You learn a lot about your capabilities and what makes you who you are in college. A final word: Decide now not to be bored. Cling to whatever thread in class that is remotely interesting. College is hard, but rewarding if you have motivation. Interest is motivating. I NEVER had a boring class. In College Algebra, my most hated and feared subject, it was our professor’s comparison in graphing to a subway and stops on it. I found some tidbit interesting in every class. In Psychological Statistics, it was our professor’s interesting lectures. He gave examples that were real-world and fascinating. He often brought interesting items to class that gave a way to apply the abstract ideas to concrete activities like rolling dice or flipping coins. In World History, it was my parents’ interest in World War II that made me want to memorize facts about it. And it helped to have a prof who was passionate about teaching it. In US History, as well, my genealogy hobby made it a lot more interesting to me. Ditto German, since I have German ancestry. It helped me decipher some records in German and I felt really good about my struggles. In Chemistry, it was building models with those wonderful plastic balls and stems. In Biology, it was thinking of what animals I could make up for my science fiction writing. And meeting animals brought into the classroom [I love animals!]

When I was a college teacher, the advice I always gave was . . . The number one underutilized resource on college campuses is office hours. Too many students avoid them, but it's throwing money away. Every day of office hours that your professor sits there without you visiting them is money down the drain. Think about it this way. You're paying $XX,000 to go to college. Most of that money is spent on salaries for people. The main thing being delivered to you is the expertise and lessons you are exposed to by faculty in the classroom. Office hours -- when faculty continue to be paid with your tuition dollars -- are like an extra free lesson. It's more of the thing you're paying for.  That's simplifying. You don't actually get lessons in office hours, in most cases. But what you do get is some one-on-one time that amplifies that value of the classroom time. Students usually leave the meeting feeling more confident, more connected, more prepared to succeed. And they are more likely to end their college careers with recommendations, introduced to the best internship opportunities, etc. Go to office hours! Even if you're not worried about anything in a particular week, stop by and say hello and let the teacher know that you are engaged and eager to do well.

These are great answers. Rather than attempting to add to an already pretty exhaustive list, I will share my experience. I was not a great high school student. I paid just enough attention to coast through. Consequently, I had little idea about effective study habits..  When I started college my first challenge was how to be a student. Many of these suggestions hit the mark with regard to the necessary behaviors for success and I quickly recognized that I needed to first change my study habits. This was not too difficult. What was far more difficult for me was to learn, “how” I learned and retained information. Let me explain. Because I had coasted through high school, I never learned “my” way of studying, the little things that helped me really learn. These included: Planning enough time to read (at some point I realized that I could read about 20 pages of technical text with high comprehension and retain the information. Any longer and I found myself having to re-read the information over and over or I would start to confuse the information in one section with another - so if I was assigned to read 100 pages of text I knew I needed to allow myself 5 hours and I would break it up accordingly),How exactly to take notes (I either tried to note too much information during a lecture and consequently spent more time writing than listening or I noted too little and couldn't remember all of the important things later),Sitting in the front of the class to force myself to pay attention and not hide in the back.To attend only morning classes because I just found that I lacked the energy to pay attention in afternoon classes (this was a challenge when selecting classes).Always challenging myself to speak up in class and volunteering to go first with speaking assignments to set the bar for everyone else by putting myself out there.Never attempting to cram on the day of a test. If I didn't know the material well enough before then, it was pretty much guaranteed that I would not learn it 15 minutes before the test.What I found interesting was that I learned more in some classes where I got a lower grade than I did in other classes where I got A’s. I now realize that it was due to working harder for that B than the A that came easy. Of course anybody who is honest will tell you that I also looked for the easy A classes to help keep my GPA up. My friends were quick to point out the easy classes for subject requirements that I had to take but didn’t really enjoy. In the end my grades were not nearly as important as I thought (from a career perspective yes, but a learning perspective much less) and unless you can apply what you learn in life, it is pretty much useless. Of course it is handy in a game of Jeopardy or Trivial pursuit. In the real world you can not wear your grades around your neck or pass out your transcripts during a meeting. People are not really too interested in your GPA. You will be measured by what you can produce, your ideas, your creativity and your work ethic. I have a sign in my office that says “Well done is better then well said.” So, my advice is to learn how to “learn” and the grades will take care of themselves.

I did very well in university despite being a lousy high school student. Actually I was a pretty bad university student too. In high school I was very hit or miss. I’d either do really well in a class or totally fail it. A lot was dependent on my personal life, drugs, work, and just being plain crazy. In university, I was a near straight A student. I got one C+ in macroeconomics because I slept through the midterm. I SLEPT THROUGH THE MIDTERM (as in didn’t write it), still did so well on the final I got a C+. A lot of people actually found this infuriating about me. Because I’m far from a model student. For one, my attendance is spotty. I’d say I attended 60% of lectures. Some classes I attended just three times. I actually would skip my own lectures to attend other lectures for courses I wasn’t even enrolled in. I never crammed before exams. You know those people who go to the library and sit around and study for days before an exam. Not me. I don’t study. I don’t see the point because I don’t forget what I learned. People taking notes in class. Yup, don’t do that either. I never took notes. Don’t need them. I just sat and listened. And if the professor repeated what was in the textbook, I wouldn’t go to that lecture. Why waste my time listening to something I had already read. When I wrote a paper, I would take my time but I wouldn’t spend that much time on it. Usually I would just start writing. Then leave it. Come back to it in a few days once I had mulled over it some more. I’d revise and revise a little bit at a time. Look for all the sources possible. Search the archives. Whatever. Data, data, data. But yeah. I wasn’t the most hard-working student. I read the material quickly and did my assignments and then the rest of the time was me-time. Write music, go to the theatre (like Shakespeare), play sports, hang out with friends, watch anime. So here, I’ll make a list of tips for getting good grades in college. Read a lot, and then read some more.Prioritize what gets results.Form your own opinions. Make your own evidence.Sleep 9 hours a day.Socialize with good people.No alcohol.Don’t take notes.Don’t take the textbook to class. Don’t take anything to class.Live in the dorm. Don’t commute.Don’t be afraid to challenge your professor and TA.Don’t be afraid to challenge yourself. This is so important. If you assume you know everything, you have no reason to go to university.Be intelligent and have a good memory.Don’t sleep through exams.Hope this helps.

When I taught freshmen courses I always included a class on how to study and how to get good grades before the first exam. These are the highlights, many others have made similar suggestions. Read all of the assigned readings. I rarely lectured on assigned readings because I thought the duplication was a waste of time for the student who could read it for themselves. I only lectured on assigned readings if the material was a little complicated or if it was essential to the course (really important)Attend all classes and take notes by hand (research has shown this is far more effective than taking notes on a computer when it comes to retention)Record the lecture if you can’t keep up taking notes, so you can listen again and get your notes filled inA week before each exam, type up your notes on a computer then go to the book and type up the major points. Combine the 2 sets of notes into one cohesive study sheet by eliminating the repeated material and organizing the material in a systematic and logical way. Use the combined notes to study the night before the exam.If you are a visual learner or artistic person, make a mind map of the combined material (google how to do it). Use your mind map to study the night before the exam.Now use your combined lecture/book notes or your mind map to study the night before the exam.Get a good nights sleep, do not stay up late studying, do not get up extra early to study. Do not cram at the last minute. Do what you can to calm yourself and reassure yourself that you know the material.Before an exam, DO NOT eat sugar or carbs. Do eat, but lightly and something high in protein and fat (this is not diet advice, rather advice to raise your blood sugar level and keep it up to feed your brain without a sugar crash) i.e. tuna salad, chicken salad, peanut butter on celery, egg salad, fried chicken etc.If you normally drink coffee or tea high in caffeine, and ONLY if you normally drink coffee or tea high in caffeine, have a strong cup before the exam without sugar. NO sodas high in sugar or your blood sugar can crash and your brain will crash in its ability to think.If you must have sugar, then if the professor allows bring M&M’s or skittles and line them up across the desk. Eat one at a time throughout the entire exam, do not eat them all before the exam ends or your blood sugar and thus brain function will crash.Do all of this and I can practically guarantee you will pass the exam. Every semester when I gave this lecture there where several students who said this advice changed their overall grades in all classes by a letter grade or more. I had one student who went from getting D’s to getting A’s in all her classes by doing this.Lastly and most importantly: 12. Do all assigned work and turn it in on time.

Many good answers here, to which I want to add only one thing. Class time is the key to making every other habit work well. If you leave class confused about the material and about what is expected of you, you will not get as much out of any subsequent hour devoted to studying, writing, doing problem sets, and so on.  And the easiest way to use class time to raise your grade is:Turn off all your electronic devices. If you have the discipline to do that, it's like a free cognitive boost. (If your professor grades on a curve, it will be a double boost, because most of your peers will not have that discipline.) Jen Senior did a nice round-up on the issue earlier this summer (The Case Against Laptops in the Classroom), but in a nutshell... Multi-tasking is harmful to cognitive work (Think You're Multitasking? Think Again). It has negative effects on focussed recall. (Scholars Turn Their Attention to Attention) Heavy multi-taskers are worse at avoiding distraction (Media multitaskers pay mental price) It is so distracting that if you can see someone else multi-tasking, you'll do worse.  (Laptop multitasking hinders classroom learning for both users and nearby peers). Any notification from your phone is distracting, even if you subsequently decide to ignore it. (Phone Notifications Are Very Distracting.)Sadly, for cognitive tasks, there is no multi to task with -- our brains are single-threaded, so multi-tasking is just a flattering word for alternating inattention. As a bonus, if your devices are off, you will have to take notes on paper, which also helps you understand what you're hearing. (The Pen Is Mightier Than the Keyboard)

From 7.28/10 to 9.7/10, I chalked down this list which actually helped me boost up my grades. Ignore the Bullshit- In my first semester, many seniors misguided us saying “A night before the exams is sufficient to get good grades”. You might end up passing the course but good grades require a little efforts. I’m not saying that you will have to toil and moil for hours daily, but yes, a little smart work and you are there!Why take risk?- Phrases like “Grades don’t matter”, “A single sheet of paper can’t decide your future” are crowd-pleasing and might be true. But not to forget, bad grades can take away good opportunities. So why take risk!?Make proper notes/Get proper notes(beforehand)- Make sure that you have all the notes containing everything the professor says in the lecture. Either attend all the classes and jot down everything yourself or if you miss some classes, take the notes from trustworthy first benchers. Because some of the teachers end up making questions on whatever they have taught in the class.Know your lecturers(from your seniors or your past experience)- Make sure you know what kind of answers are appreciated by your lecturer- Quantity answers or Quality answers. Some teachers prefer lengthy answers over quality answers. So make sure that your answer sheet is as fat and chunky as possible in this case. But yes, if a teacher likes quality answers, write precise points and don’t beat about the bush.Don’t underestimate anything- If you have covered almost every topic in the syllabus and just left 1/32 part of it, then 99% chances are that a question will asked from that uncovered part. How annoying and regretful would it be? So do not undervalue even a trivial topic!Last Year Question Papers- Take the last year question papers from your seniors and analyse the type of questions asked.Don’t wait for the deadline- Complete the homework and assignment yourself on the night it is given rather than copying it a night before the deadline. Wouldn’t it be better to take pressure and accomplish the task a few days ahead of schedule, rather than working right up to the last minute?Healthy Discussions- Three hours before the exams, I and my roommate discuss everything that we have studied. In this way, whatever topics we have missed unknowingly are covered easily and everything is brushed up.Answer sheet hacks- Neat answer sheets with good hand writing, writing down answers in bullets rather than long paragraphs, underlining the important points can work wonders.Each individual has his/her own way of dealing with things. Draft your own plan. All the best! Happy Reading!

Engage the professors and TAs The number 1 rule to getting awesome grades in college is to always, always engage the professor and the TA of that class, this means:  Do the reading before classPay attention and ask questions in classGo to office hours to clarify your doubts, or enhance your understanding of a topicGo to your Prof./TA after a test to understand why you made certain mistakes - please, please don't ask for more partial credit, it's annoying, and the extra 1 point does nothing for your grade. However, understanding why you made a mistake is immensely valuable. There are many reasons why this works, including:  These are just good habits that will increase your learning in general, like reading ahead and paying attention/asking questions in class.You will build a good reputation with the teaching staff - so in any borderline situations, they will give you the benefit of the doubt. Meaning if you are border of B+ and A- --> you will get the A- 95% of the time. The professor/TA will pay more attn to you and hence your personal learning will increase. Learning from your mistakes/engaging in that way will help you reduce mistakes over time (maybe this is obvious).In general, I believe that study habits really need to be based on your own optimization of how you learn best. However, given that, engaging with the teaching staff will be the biggest way to boost your grade.  I know this works because it was the biggest change in my own behavior between freshman and later years. It made a HUGE impact. Good Luck!

The first time I went to college for an undergraduate degree I flunked out of college. When I finally got my degree decades later I graduated summa cum laude and got an award from my department based in the quality of my writing.  What did I do differently the second time around? Well, here's a list. It may not be fully comprehensive and it is not in a particular order. Start with the basics and work your way up. If something seemed too easy but it was a requirement, I took it. Introductory courses for a field don't give you the enormous depth of knowledge that a specialist has, but it gives you some of the breadth you need to move on. If a course seemed challenging but would build upon something I'd already learned, I took that. Focus on academics. I was less focused in my schoolwork my first time through, worrying more about socializing (poorly, but that's another Quora) and how to avoid campus dining than I was about much of my studies. My most recent tour saw me focus first on getting my studies under control, figuring out my workload, and only then looking for other things to do on campus. Ask questions when you need answers. Good professors and TAs will not spoon feed you answers during an exam, but if you have a question that is not utter foolishness and is within the scope of the class they will do their utmost to answer it. I asked fewer questions my first time through. Take good notes. This does not mean transcribing absolutely everything. It means writing whatever you can that will help you remember key points. Do what works. Learn from everybody. You can learn a lot from your classmates, though not necessarily about that class. Your classmates will join you in study groups and help you blow off steam if you need to. If your classmates ask, teach them. If you have a good handle on the material and your grades have been good, offering to study with classmates and help them understand points they are having trouble with can actually help you more thoroughly understand the class materials. The last time I did a small study group with a couple of classmates they thanked me afterwards, saying I'd been clearer on the explanation than the professor. Read the materials. Some classes will just summarize the materials you read, but if you read the materials you will have a better chance of understanding and organizing it in your head. Other classes expand upon the materials and it will be pretty obvious if you haven't read them unless you already have a very strong foundation in the subject. Be interested! If you are bored with the class you won't do as well. My introduction to political science teacher mentioned that many polisci majors actually got a B of some sort taking that class, even if they got an A in much of the rest of the coursework. Also, if you have a wide variety of interests you can expand your knowledge in each of them. I took courses outside my major in environmental studies, writing, sociology, statistics, and would have taken more economics and business courses if I'd had the time and energy. Schedule wisely. My first time around, the university kept not giving me the time slots for classes that I requested despite having space in those slots. My last place did not do this to me. As much as possible create a schedule that works for you, your sleep habits, any job you might have, your dietary needs and any religious needs. While schoolwork should be a top priority, it's much tougher for it to be the top priority if you are underslept, underfed and overstressed about scheduling conflicts. Do the assignments and do them to spec. This seems like a no brainer but it's not. A few times I didn't do homework to spec when I first went to university, and there were a few times I just blew off my homework. Like I said, there are reasons I flunked out and some of them were all me.My last time around I always made sure my assignments were completed and answered what the assignment asked for. I did not always get an A but I got them more often than not. One time when I reviewed a classmate's paper before it was due I found that she hadn't directly addressed the assignment at all, instead ducking and trying to answer something else. I suggested she rewrite it but she declined. She got a poor grade on that paper. The professor for that class currently has copies of my work for that course as writing samples to show students who need help. Go. To. Class. I skipped a number of classes my first time through, sometimes oversleeping, sometimes socializing. My second time through I went to class every time unless I was very sick or had a major project that could not be done at another time, like a trip to DC or studying for an upcoming GRE. If sick, get notes when possible. If you have a major project, check with your professors in advance if it is OK to miss a class or two. I basically took a week off of some classes so I could study for the GREs, but only after talking with the professors. They all said I was fine to focus on the GREs. Don't routinely overload your brain. You will get overloads at peak periods sometimes, like finals or midterms. That's understandable. If it looks like you are overloading every week then you have a problem. In that case, step back and see if it is something you will get past quickly or if it looks like you'll drop much of what you're juggling. I did drop a class my final semester, not because I was uninterested in it or doing poorly in the class, but because that class was the one that over scheduled me and kept me from focusing on my other commitments. Work with teachers you understand. I had a couple of teachers I couldn't understand my first time through and who couldn't help me with my questions. I should have looked for another teacher to teach me those concepts but I didn't. This is one reason I failed my first time through. I didn't have that problem the last time around. Figure out what you can schedule socially outside of classes and homework. Learning is the primary part of your degree, but making friends and influencing people is another important part. My first time through my priorities were socializing first, schoolwork second, and helping out last. This is not a recipe for success in school, though it might work in some networking meetings. My last time around I put schoolwork first, helping out second and socializing last. Interestingly, I got in more socializing from helping out and I made some good contacts with people I like. This can happen when you work on the school newspaper and serve in student government. When possible, work from your strengths. Your major should be based on your talents and interests, not something other people tell you to do that you are thoroughly uninterested in learning about. You may have to take a few courses like that for your major, and you may have to slog through those. Learning should be more about the joy of understanding than the dull grind of cramming stuff in your head.  You have already gotten some good advice. If my perspective can help then you are welcome to it.

If you ever wondered – “Are good grades important?”, rest assured that having them is better than not having them. Good grades translate to more academic opportunities, job opportunities, and even money. Here are some tips to get good grades in college. Learn how to learn Find out how you learn best. Certain learning methods don’t work for some people. There are audio learners, visual learners, hands-on learners, etc. Find which way you learn best and focus on learning through that method.Read the textbook. It likely has all the information that you have to know to do well on your assignments and exams.Study smart by creating detailed study guides, quizzing with another Learner, and getting help from teachers when you need it.Learn how to research and find information. Being able to research subjects and find good sources is a skill that will help in school and beyond.Stay organized Use a planner. Record all your assignments, quizzes, exams, and appointments in it.Create a study schedule. Designate specific times that you will do homework, study, and complete assignments.Have all the folders, three-ring binders, and notebooks you need. Have these for each class and keep all your notes and assignments in them.Make sure to have a neat workspace. A cluttered desk is a cluttered mind.Prioritize classes, homework, exams, and tasks. Allot the appropriate time for things that require more effort from you.Attend every class (in mind and body) Attend every class, not almost every class. When you miss a class, you cannot make it up, it’s gone. So be on time for every class.Sit in the front of the class to help you pay attention and get all the information being taught. Hey, it might also rub your teacher the right way.Stay engaged in class. Just being there is not enough. You have to be listening to the professor, taking notes, participating, and asking questions to be fully engaged.Taking good notes has multiple benefits. Note taking can help you learn and retain the lesson and you can use the notes later to help you prepare for exams. Good notes correlate with good grades.Learn with others Learning with others can help you get good grades!Find another Learner (study buddy). Here are 6 reasons to find a Learner.Find a Knower (tutor) to teach you. They have the knowledge, experience, and teaching ability help you learn and get good grades.Learning with others brings more teaching and learning opportunities, teamwork on assignments, and better test preparation.Do your work Always complete your homework and assignments immediately. Getting them done early will allow you to focus on other things.Don’t procrastinate; that will put unnecessary pressure on you to complete assignments which will take away from the learning opportunity.Complete every homework and assignment you have. These make up a large portion of your final grade. Ensure that you get all of those points just in case you lose points in other areas such as test and projects.Know how to take exams Preparing for exams happens long before the night before an exam. Throughout the class, you should have taken quality notes, reviewed, as well as completed all homework and assignments. Test preparation should be reviewing what you already know.Know what to expect in each exam; understand the format and subject material on the test.Prepare with another Learner. Combining knowledge and quizzing each other will help improve understanding and retention for exams.Don’t cram and get a good night’s sleep. The night before the exam is not the time to learn the material. Hopefully, you spent the weeks before this point preparing so you can just review then get to sleep early to be at your best on exam day.Getting good grades is not as difficult as some might think, but it’s also not easy. It requires discipline, consistency, and hard work. Qualities such as those are what separates people in the classroom, the workplace, and in life. Do your best to do well in school, it will give you more options in life. Our community has thousands of Learners and Knowers who are all striving to crush it in school and the workplace. Join the LearnX community to meet people like you.

Freshman and Sophomore years are tough partly because you need to pass all the required courses which generally have little to do with your chosen major but you can get through it by hard work and time management. By the time you are a Junior you’ll have the rhythms and routines down pat and will know just how hard to apply yourself to get top grades. What is great about being a junior is that the focus changes to your chosen major which if you are lucky means that you can really sink your teeth into the coursework. If you are really lucky you realize that everything that you do is no longer just about the grade but about personal achievement. You might find yourself working harder than you ever imagined you would but it’s okay because you will find that once you reach that level of commitment and interest the grades are besides the point. Once you get there the professors will begin to think of you as more of a colleague than a nameless face. You will stand out not because of grades but for reaching a level of synthesis allowing for mastery. And so how do you get good grades in college? You get good grades in college by not focusing on the grade but rather by focusing on achievement; if you can share the professor’s enthusiasm for the subject, own the discipline and display a degree of mastery the grades will take care of themselves.

High Caffeine is just one thing for High GRADES.  I don’t know about you, but this is the time where my stress (and caffeine) levels are at an all-time-high because of assignments and reports and of course, finals. I shifted my stress part (Assignments, reports, etc) onto online study help and I’d share some tips to study effectively for your exams. These tips and online tutorials have really helped me the past year, and hopefully they’ll help you out too! USE FLASH CARDS AND TUTORIALS I am honestly not that good at anything science-related so flashcards basically saved me when it came to History. TUTORIALS are available online in shape of study sets, tests, videos and diagrams to help you better understand and remember the material, which is a life saver, especially if you are a visual learner. GET TO KNOW YOUR PROFESSORS This one is about to get quite sappy. We have all had teachers in our lives that have shaped the way we perceive ourselves and the world around us. They provide not only lectures on math and science, but great life lessons to carry on past the school. PLAN ASSIGNMENTS AHEAD and SET REMINDERS FOR DUE DATES If you can manage it, you want to try to plan every major assignment two weeks in advance. This little piece of advice saved me so much last term. I pinned all the assignments on planner and started working two weeks earlier for large assignments so that I have no burden on deadlines. I used to take help with online tutorials and published materials to get ahead. HAND WRITE YOUR NOTES Then come the NOTES. Your notes are yours only and nobody cares how rough or bad they look. You should from the start day make your all notes your way and only your way. You don’t have to worry how bad your notes look as far as they are helpful to you. Bonus point if you rewrite your lecture notes every night and color code them. STUDY THE NIGHT BEFORE AND THE MORNING OF CLASS Not only do I study the night before, but I also study the morning of a major test. Studying the night before and the morning of, right before class starts, allows your brain to retain as much information as possible. I truly believe this is one of the major reasons I get A’s on all of my tests.

Studying to Learn or Studying for an Exam? Studying purely for the sake of learning is the ideal situation, but in the real world, we’re usually studying to pass an exam. What’s the difference? Strategy versus tactics. Every good Quora post should include a classic quote, so here’s Sun Tzu: “Strategy without tactics is the slowest route to victory. Tactics without strategy is the noise before defeat.” If you’re focused on studying for the sake of learning, it’s all about tactics - otherwise known as study skills. But if you have an exam looming, it’s important to start with strategy. You need to know where to focus your time and effort before you begin using the how. Makes sense, right? If you’re like the average student, you’re probably short on time, which makes a strategic approach all the more important. This video explains the 6 steps for strategic exam preparation.  Whether you’re cramming for an exam tomorrow or you’re super organized and you’re preparing three months in advance, you’ll follow the same steps. So that’s strategy, now what about specific tactics? The ANSWER Method: 6 Essential Study Skills How do most students study? If you took a survey of typical students, I bet the most popular study techniques would include: Re-readingHighlightingSummarizingFlashcardsThere's only one problem with that list... ... none of them are highly effective! What REALLY works? What does academic research recommend you should do? What are the most effective ways to study? Here are the top six tactics.  Now I'm a simple guy, and some of these academic words were too complicated for me. So I've changed them up a bit and put them into an acronym that's easy to recall. Here are the top six, evidence-based study strategies you should make sure you use: The ANSWER Method Ask, Explain & Connect (or Elaboration in academic speak) No Cramming (Spaced Practice) Switch (Interleaving) Words & Visuals (Dual Coding) Examples (Concrete Examples) Recall What You Know (Retrieval Practice) Watch the video above and you'll understand what each of them are, why they're beneficial, and how to use them. If you thought this answer was valuable, please give it an upvote so other people will know it's worth checking out too. Thanks!﻿

In each course in college, do the following: Read the syllabus carefully as soon as you get it, to learn what the professor thinks you should be able to accomplish by the end of the course. Note the due dates of all assignments and exams in your calendar. Do the assigned readings before course meetings so you can get the most out of your time in the classroom. Start course assignments early so you have time to really think about them, set them aside, and return for a fresh perspective.  Do the work yourself:  cheating on homework by looking up the answers online will just make it more likely that you'll do badly on exams. Ask questions in class. Visit your professor's office hours and ask more questions. Join a study group to get practice in discussing the material. Think about how the current course relates to material from past courses or the other ones you're taking alongside it. Putting together the big picture will make each course more understandable. When studying for exams, do practice problems you've never seen before from scratch, try writing timed practice essays, or write up an annotated course outline summarizing what you've learned. Reading over your notes isn't an effective way to study. You have to do something active that forces you to examine or apply the material in a fresh way. Above all, convince yourself that the material is fascinating and that you love it. That makes it easier to spend time thinking about it.
