Overall, the key is to achieve and demonstrate a mastery of the assigned subject-matter; by law, they can only grade you on that.  First, I have to refer to http://HowToStudy.com, which contains most of what I explain. Next, you have to take an active role in your academic career, and make it your sole priority. The first order of business is the teacher; scope out the different teachers for each course you want to take next term, by sitting in on classes and students that they think. Also get a look at the class textbook for each class, and consider this as well. Once you know which instructors you like, ask them a few questions about the class during office-hours.  You also need a schedule, to plan what you will do to succeed, and when; a good plan is essential.  For studying, be sure to stay ahead of the class by one lesson, since the purpose of the class is to review and clarify the subject-matter, not to introduce it; I did this by taking book-notes on my notebook in black text, and then during class I'd  follow along with my notes, and write after it in red text whatever the teacher said about that topic, since that's particularly important  (a good way to do this is to have red *'s in your notes, and then copy-and-paste it to produce the red font).  Then right after class, I'd convert all my notes into questions and answers, to test myself on the material, and be sure I knew the answers. I'd also make the questions boldfaced, and the answers in plain text. For example a question from law school Civil Procedure would be  List the things needed for a court to be able to try a case? In Personam jurisdiction, Subject Matter jurisdiction, and Venue. Or in Abnormal Behavior psychology,  Explain Alzheimer's Disease A mental illness congenitally carried in Chromosome 21, responsible for the metabolism of protein A-68, which is necessary for the production of the primary neurotransmitter acetylcholine. Symptoms include.... Etc.  Be sure you can answer all the questions from memory, before reading for  the next class, otherwise you'll lose information. Also try to get hold of past exams from the class, as a source of questions, as well as an indication of what you'll need to study most. By exam-time, you should have a thorough mastery of the class objectives.  A primary element of academic success, however, is the time involved; few academic institutions emphasize this, since they'd have few students if they explained that a standard 12-credit hour semester is a full-time job, requiring over 40 hours/week for class-time and homework; as a result, most schools are rather vague on what's required, leading to late-night cram sessions before exams, which are only marginally effective on the exam, and lead to little benefit from the class itself-- vs. a thorough mastery of the information presented therein, as established by a well-designed program with clear objectives.

People always ask how to get good grades, but the never ask how to learn the material. The best way to get good grades is to learn the material. That is also the best use of your time, because it pays rewards for the rest of your life. Here are my standard tips for some behaviors that will help you learn the material: Read the textbook chapter BEFORE the class period where the teacher will discuss that chapter. You are not trying to memorize everything in the chapter, but you are trying to become familiar with the vocabulary and understand how the principles in the chapter relate to each other.Sit in the 2nd or 3rd row in your class, on whatever side of the classroom that suits you best.Raise your hand and answer a question or offer a comment 1–3 times per class period (no less than 1, no more than 3 - 2 is really good). Don’t be the first person to raise your hand; give your classmates the chance to participate first. If none of them choose to do so, then it is your turn to do so. You are not trying to dominate the discussion - you are just showing your teacher that you understand the material.Take good notes. Since you have read the chapter, you don’t have to take notes about what all the new words mean - that is in the textbook. Your notes should focus on the examples that your teacher uses to illustrate the principles that you are learning about.Do the homework.Go to the teacher’s (or the TA’s) office hours at least twice per semester. Don’t go the first week. Don’t try to suck up to the teacher. Either go and ask for help learning some of the principles of the class (if you need help - don’t try to fake needing help) or ask about career fields that pertain to the class. Don’t tell the teacher that this is your life-long ambition, just take this opportunity to learn about some possibilities for your future.Learn the material as you go - do not plan on cramming for the exam. Cramming for the exam doesn’t help you do better on the exam, and it ensures that you aren’t learning the material. If you want to do well on the exam, learn the material as you go along, make sure that you are trying to understand the things that are being taught. Read the chapter again, review the vocabulary, and then go over your notes to understand the examples that the teacher used, and understand why those examples are good.

This is down to you, and you’re already on the right path! This sounds a little simple, but you have to work hard and be consistent in what you do. I’ve noticed in others, the one thing that isn’t mentioned, is that you’ll need to work consistently and that requires discipline and working on yourself. So to add to other comments, apply these to your study time: Work hard and plan a schedule for when you will studyReward yourself if you’re working, do NOT study 24/7, it’s not healthyTry to understand the topic until you can explain it to someone elseRead carefully, and bullet point your tasks when writing essays/workNot only ask questions in class but be more intuitive, google your questions, understand them as much as you canYou ARE capable of great things, never doubt yourself if you’re strugglingAnd one last-time, study in a healthy environment and reward yourself. take regular breaks, watch TV when you have time and make time to de-stress yourself.Achieving good grades require structure, and find the right balance. Source/Credibility: I have helped source and curate more than 2,500 student advice articles and helpful videos for student for universitycompare.com One of the largest student advice archives online:Student Advice Archives | University Compare We help more than 2.2m students every year at University Compare and this question comes up in more presentations than you’d think!

A lot of good advice here. Just a few comments, which maybe repeat some things that some others have said. It is really important to try to get a head start if at all possible. Try to get the textbook as early as possible before the first class, do an initial cover-to-cover skim, and try to at least read the first chapter - it will be a good bet to be your first assignment, even if you don’t have the syllabus yet. If the subject matter is really new to you, take a trip to the library and/or browse the internet (i.e. Wikipedia) to try to get a brief “birds eye” introduction of the subject. Once you have that head start, try to stay at least a week ahead throughout the semester if at all possible - you’ll be very glad you did when you get to finals.Develop and use a note-taking system that works well for you. The most elegant system in the world is worthless if it doesn’t work for you and you can’t/don’t use it. I would strongly suggest that you come up with a system that combines textbook notes and lecture notes in one place. This will then become what you review before exams. I am not a big fan of marking up textbooks, and not just because of the hit you take on re-sale value; I just doubt that going back through a textbook is a very efficient way to review for most people. A set of really good notes that distills the most important points from both the text and the lecture will serve you a lot better.As you are doing your preliminary reading in advance, make notes of any questions you might need answers for in class. Review your study notes and these questions just before class, so you will be prepared to fully participate and make the best use of class time. I’d suggest sitting toward the front - that’s where the best students sit, and where the profs assume the best students sit.I would also suggest developing a separate system for learning and reviewing vocabulary. Every subject will have its own specialized lingo, and knowing the proper and important terms and what they mean is almost always going to be one of the things tested on exams. Flash cards are the classic study tool for these, and they have the advantage of being handy for drilling yourself during transit or other unproductive moments. Again, if something else works better for you, then use what works.Do all the homework yourself if possible, but get help if you are the least bit unsure whether or not your answers are correct. Don’t hesitate to go to the prof during office hours if you are not sure how to work a problem. I’m not a big fan of study groups (which, unless they are highly motivated students, can become cut-up/goof-off groups) with one exception: it is a good idea for you and several other GOOD students to check your work against each other prior to turning it in. Better to find out if you have misunderstood something or just gotten it wrong prior to submitting it.Consider using supplemental learning materials if they will help you. I am thinking here of Cliffs Notes for literature, Schaum’s Outlines for math, science, and engineering courses, and College Outline Series for many other undergraduate courses. (There may be equivalents of these in other countries.) It is an extra investment of time to use these, and some students won’t benefit all that much from them. If the standard textbook and lecture just are not quite doing it for you, though, then sometimes a supplement will help. Another possibility might be to get hold of a different textbook. There are usually going to be several different textbooks available on any subject. The one your prof (or maybe their department) selected may or may not be the best one for you. Sometimes they pick a text because it is cheaper, or just because it is what the prof is familiar with, or sometimes even because it is what the prof or their colleague in their department authored; none of these assure that it is really the best one for you. Given the choice of struggling through a class and doing poorly or spending the extra money for a much better text, I think I know what my choice would be.Find tutoring assistance if you really need help. I mean it. Especially for the lower-level courses, there are probably tutors available. In many cases the university will have a program where people are lined up to be available for this. If not, then just start asking around for grad students in the subject - there will always be someone interested in making a few extra dollars for what (to them) is easy work. Don’t give up and accept a poor grade - fight and try for a better one.Also get an early start on research papers, and be well-organized and thorough in your approach. Discussing possible topics is a good excuse for meeting with your prof during office hours early in the semester. Most profs will be impressed that you are wanting to get on the ball, and will try to be helpful. It may take several visits, because a good (and high-graded) paper is going to require your narrowing your subject to a much greater extent than you might initially realize. For most students, the subject matter in their class is going to be pretty new, so knowing enough to pick a good topic will be difficult. Talking to grad students and bouncing ideas off them might be helpful as well. Whatever topic you narrow down to, you need to gather as much relevant research materials as you can. ASK THE REFERENCE LIBRARIAN FOR HELP! That is what they are there for, and are a greatly underutilized resource. Be aware that not everything is available on the internet or in the university; some materials may have to be ordered through interlibrary loan. This is another big reason why you need to get the earliest possible start. When it comes down to writing your paper, get at it as soon as possible. Be scrupulous in your citations (and make sure you are using the citation style that your prof wants). If you are someone who has difficulty turning out perfect documents that are error-free, then I wouldn’t hesitate about paying someone to turn your draft into a perfect final ready for submission; you need to line up such a person early, not at the last minute.If you do all of the above, then you should be done with your studying and have a complete set of review notes well before your final exam, and you should also have any papers or other final assignments turned in and out of the way. This should put you in a very good position going into the final. Try to be well-rested before exam day. Some of the supplemental materials mentioned above have practice exams, or you might be able to find these elsewhere; for some students, doing a practice exam before exam day might be helpful. If you find you are having trouble with something, try to have one last meeting with the prof to go over it before exam day.Try to find some break time for some physical activity. You’ll find yourself having more energy and better retention if you do.

"How" is one question. However, the more important one would be: Why? or What for? Do these excellent grades really lead to better employment opportunities? There is one place where grades do really matter - a graduate school. And a college itself (students keep calculating and comparing their GPA).  The real value of doing these calculations outside of college, however, remains unclear. I am not, honestly, aware of any other place that clearly does differentiate between A plus and C students when they hire them. In my opinion, getting straight As is more of a matter of personal achievement or personal satisfaction. A lot more so than being a critical career-related step. There is hardly any tangible benefit of being an A plus student other than perceptional or psychological (unless you have already decided to go to graduate school). In fact, this "A plus or nothing" mentality comes at a price.  The price is time.  Yes, of course, you can beat any test or assignment. But this is never possible without a serious investment of time.  This time can be also spent somewhere else, and in a more productive way for your career - e.g. talking to people, making connections, learning tricks of trade from people involved in this trade. I would certainly think that this approach brings a lot better return on the investment of time than does a personal satisfaction through high grades. In general, our education system should find a way to reward students for creativity, critical thinking and real-life results, and not for robotic memorization just to pass the test.  The problem is actually a lot deeper in many Asian countries, where the system is designed to produce test-taking robots and not people who are learning something to apply it to real-world tasks. This has got to change.

We should distinguish two things first. Great students almost always have great grades. But, those with great grades do not necessarily make great students. Why? Understand that school is kind of like a game, everyone is competing to get the highest marks. Naturally, those who exploit the system to get the good grades, i.e. cheat, brown-nose, take easy courses, or easy professors, can get away with doing much less and end up being identical on paper. This is also the case across majors being studied. There are many reasons someone might want to do this. It could be because grad schools really care about how nice your gpa looks. It could be for certain internships, or positions in government at the university. Everyone has reasons for wanting this, but it is universally accepted that a higher gpa will gain you better entrance into a number of things. At worst, it won’t hurt your chances or make it worse off than if you had a lower gpa. At Berkeley, you can see that there are quit a few majors with average gpas hovering around 3.0 or less: biology, mathematics, statistics, physics. So relatively speaking, a good grade would be a B in those technical courses. You’d be sitting in classes with some of the smartest kids in the country. If you sift through the majors, you’ll find that you can take languages, visual studies, or education and have an easier time. So to answer this part of the question, I would say that it depends what you want to do. If you want just great grades, there are many ways to do this. Now, if you want to actually be a great student, that requires a plethora of things. The most important, I would say, is an actual fascination with learning. This will guarantee that you are engaged in the material that you are trying to learn. If you truly love learning quantum mechanics, you will probably end up doing well just do to your persistence and engagement. Asking questions, no matter how stupid you think they are, are critical to your understanding of highly complex subjects. Great students are fantastic learners, with an appetite to actually gain useful information that either models the world around them or describes beauty in things that are otherwise invisible to the eye. At the end of the day, it depends purely on who you want to be.

The transition from high school to college can be tricky, mainly because there is a lot of structure to your day in high school but, in college, you are expected to create your own structure and manage your time well. The good news is that there is SO much more time in college. If you spend a few minutes each day planning, you can get all of your work done, including studying, and also have plenty of free time to enjoy the full college experience. This has become one of the most common questions I get asked. And with good reason. As technology has improved and advanced, it has also increased the frequency with which we are constantly distracted and interrupted. This can make it hard (if not almost impossible) to get your work done while making it incredibly easy to procrastinate! I think you will find my recent answer to this similar question helpful: Sharon Feldman Danzger's answer to What are the best study tips ever?  Photo source: Pixabay Our brains are all wired differently, so a method or system that is perfect for one person won’t work for another. The biggest issue I see is that students believe they can study effectively for long stretches of time. But research shows that our brain can stay engaged and focused for 90 minutes or less. This means we need to plan our days to have frequent breaks so our fatigued brain can relax and reset. Otherwise, we become easily distracted and ineffective. Trying the system outlined below will head you in the right direction. It’s easier to get motivated to study if you have specific time frames and goals and scheduled breaks. And the concepts translate and work great in the working world as well! 7 STEPS TO STUDY MORE EFFECTIVELY IN LESS TIME: When you receive an assignment, break it into small tasks. You know the joke: "How do you eat an elephant?" One bite at a time. Accomplishing small pieces of the larger task will empower and encourage you to keep going. For each small piece, estimate how long you think it will take (be generous, most things take longer than we expect.) Then assign a degree of difficulty - you can create your own scale or simply use 1 to represent easy, 2 for medium, and 3 for hardIf you have a big exam to study for, break it into bite-size pieces. If your attention span is 15–20 minutes, use that as your guide. List each step and the estimated time next to it as well as the degree of difficulty.Each evening, look at what needs to get done. Each task should have an estimated time assigned to its well as a degree of difficulty. Update the list for new assignments and adjust estimated time and degree of difficulty, as needed.Take out your calendar and be sure to schedule. Fill in classes and other ‘fixed’ variables. Then, look at your list of tasks and decide which need to get done immediately. By prioritizing your to-do list every day, nothing will fall through the cracks or be forgotten. Your calendar is a great tool and will serve as your road map each day.Consider the times during the day when you are most alert and attentive. Everyone has windows of peak performance. Put simply, it’s the time of day when you find it easiest to focus and get your most difficult work done. Schedule your harder tasks during these times but be sure to allow for regular breaks. If you find yourself tired and sluggish in the late afternoon, be sure to plan easier work to be done during that time.The Pomodoro method suggests 25 minutes of concentration followed by 5 minutes of relaxation. You can use this as a guide or adjust the 25 to 20 minutes if that’s your optimal working time.Scheduling a specific time to study and get work done. Making appointments in your calendar to get your tasks done will enable you to get your studying and assignments done more efficiently. You will also find that scheduling out your time makes you realize that when you work effectively, there is plenty of time to do things you enjoy (dinner with friends, exercise, movies, etc.) It may not be as much time as you would like (especially during finals) but you will spend less time studying and find that the time you spend is more effective.Best of luck! For more productivity tips, please check out my blog or recently released book, Super-Productive: 120 Strategies to Do More and Stress Less. Sharon

response.answer_text: If you are struggling with grades and interested in raising your grade point average, take a close look at these 10 tips for getting better grades. 1. Attend every class If you want good grades in college, you must attend every class, not almost every class. The importance of regular class attendance cannot be overemphasized. When you miss classes, you miss lectures, notes, discussions, explanations, and assignments. Do not think that missing a class won’t make a difference. You cannot make up what you miss. 2. Master Your Professors Every professor has a different personality and system for running his/her classes, so it makes sense as early in the semester as possible to learn what the professor wants. Here are some ways to master your professors: Understand course expectations. Most professors give out a class syllabus during the first week of classes — and it is your responsibility to know deadlines and all the requirements for the course.Understand professors on personal level. Rather than viewing the professor as some figurehead at the front of the class who decides your fate in some abstract way, get to know your professor as a person. Visit him or her during office hours, or stay after class.Communicate with professors when you are struggling. Especially at larger colleges and universities, the professor won’t know when you are struggling, so if you are having problems with the course work or the tests, schedule an appointment to meet with the professor and get the help you need.3. Be organized: Use a student planner: take this to each class and record all assignments. Also use your planner to keep track of tests and quizzes, activities and appointments.Break down assignments: large assignments are more manageable if you break them down into smaller parts. Completing these smaller portions over a longer period of time will allow you more time to focus.Use three-ring binders for class notes: this type of note book works well because handouts can easily be inserted and if you end up missing a class you can also insert a copy of someone else’s notes where they belong.Organize and save computer work: make sure that all your work on the computer is saved and saved often, and that you have back up files.4. Use Time Wisely Even if you do not procrastinate and are the most organized person in the world, time can be one of your biggest enemies in college. Here are some tips for using time wisely: Don’t overextend yourselfBe organized: see number 2 above!Schedule 90 minute study sessions: set a specific time to get your studying done and make sure you will not be interrupted. During these study sessions, don’t do anything else but study!Make ‘to do’ lists and prioritize tasks: make a daily list of the things you need to do. Rate each item as an A (must do today), B (should do today), or C (would like to do today, but can wait). Listing and prioritizing your tasks only takes a few minutes but it is a great way to organize your time. Focus on one task at a time until everything is completed5. Take Good Notes: tests usually cover materials that the instructor has presented in class. Therefore, it is important to have good class notes. Be an active listener: when your actively listening, your not just hearing the words, but you are also thinking about and trying to understand the information being presented.Taking notes can help you pay attention and stay focused.Recognize important information: anything the instructor writes on the board is important. In your notes, underline or star the most important information so you can pay special attention to it when studying.6. Know How to Read a Textbook: Knowing how to scan, read and review will make it much easier for you to understand and remember what you read. Scan: scanning gives you a quick overview of the material you’re going to be reading. To scan, read the title, subtitle, and everything in bold and italic print. Look at the pictures, captions, charts, graphs, and read the introduction, the summary and the review questions. Read: when your reading has a purpose, you have a reason to stay focused and your comprehension improves. Review: to review, first ask yourself ‘what is the main idea’ and then go back to the beginning and go through the same process you did when you scanned the material. This time, as you scan restate the main idea of each passage using your own words. 7. Study Smart: Students who study smart find themselves spending less time of studying and still getting better grades. Find a good place to study: make sure the area is free of distractions.Know your learning style: we all learn differently! Some learn best by seeing the material (visual learner), some learn best from hearing the material (auditory learner), and some learn best by doing (kinesthetic learner). As a rule, the more senses you involve and the wider variety of methods you use while studying, the more you remember.Organize your study time: before you begin, make a plan. Decide exactly what you want to get done. Always allow more time than you think you will need and prioritize your work to make sure that you have enough time for the things that are most important. Do difficult tasks first while you are most alert and fresh and remember to take regular short study breaks.9. Be a Good Test-Taker Just about all college classes have exams, and sometimes the exams are the major portion of your final grade, so it’s important to become a good test-taker. Here are some hints: Know what to expect on exams. Every professor has a style of test development, so obtain old copies or ask the professor directly. Know the types of questions that will be asked — as well as the content that will be covered.Read questions carefully and plan answers. Take your time at the beginning of the test to read through all the instructions and make a plan of attack.Pace yourself so you have plenty of time to complete all parts. And know the point v alues of questions, so you can be sure to complete the most important ones first in case time does run out.Ask questions. If you don’t understand something, or need clarification of the question, ask the professor. Don’t wait to get the exam back and find you answered a question the wrong way.Here are some tips I think it may help you a lot to get good grades in college. Yet, each one has their own style of learning, there are no fixed rules in learning. Find yourself anyway suitable and sufficient to your own.

How to get good grades is a common question asked by the students at any level of education. The reason is everyone wants to score good grades in their examinations. It just not provide mental happiness to the students but also play a crucial role in the success of the students. Get higher grades in school can be a lot easier than getting high grades in college. Getting good grades is also helpful in winning competitive scholarships. Today I am going to share with you the best and most effective tips on how to get good grades in exams. Just studying is not enough for getting good grades. You need to have a solid strategy and plan that will help you to regain your focus and help you to achieve good grades. Tips on how to get good grades: 1. Motivate yourself Self-motivation is the key to success for every student. It is pretty often that the students lose their confidence when they don’t get good grades. But you should not make the same mistakes as other students do. You may not get satisfied with your grades sometimes, but at that moment, you should maintain your self-confidence to be in the game of getting good grades. You should believe in yourself to stay focused on your work. The best way to motivate yourself is to create some milestones for yourself. You can create a series of milestones. When you start working to achieve those milestones than in every achievement, you will boost your self-confidence. And this confidence will lead you to get good grades in your exams. 2. Listen and participate in the class A student who does participate in the class always gets more grades than the students who don’t. But listen and participate in the class is not easy for any students, especially for the shy one. But it showcases the teacher that you care about the topic and you want to score high grades. The teacher gives the grades based on various factors. Apart from that if you participate in the class, then you may get more awareness about the topic. Along with that if you listen to your mentor or teacher carefully, then you can learn a lot more than the self-study. It will help you to prepare for the exams more effectively. Thus it helps you to get good grades in your exams. Besides, if you’re a weak student, then you can sit closer to the teacher so that the teacher can know more about you and find your weakness. Apart from that, you can also write down some questions before the class and then ask them to the teacher to clear your doubts. 3. Take thorough notes during a class Notes are quite helpful in getting high grades. You should make notes during the class. Notes help you to cover the important information about the topic. You can create the notes by listening to your teacher. Apart from that, you can also create the notes of the important topic with the help of some reference book of your topic. It will help you to prepare for the exams more efficiently. Sometimes the students just need to have a look at the notes, and then they prepare for the exams within a few hours. Apart from that, these notes are also helpful just before the last few minutes of the exams. 4. Do not hesitate to ask for help Majority of students does this mistake. I don’t why they always have hesitation while asking the help from the teacher. The students need to take help from the teacher. Even intelligent students also look for help from the teacher. Because the students can’t cover everything about the topic without taking help from the teacher. It is quite common for tough subjects. You should ask for help from your teachers and your peers in the class. It helps you to learn more about the topic and clear your doubts without much effort. Apart from that, you can also ask your parents for help if they can help you with the topic. Along with that, you can also ask them for the private tutor, who will help you to learn more about the topic. 5. Stay focused during your homework Focus is the key factor in how to get good grades. Lack of focus will not help you to good core grades; You need to be well focused during your homework. Did you know homework plays a crucial role in your academic scores? Homework helps you to get ready for the exams and learn more deeply about the topic. That’s why you need to stay focused during your homework. Now the question is, how we can do that? The best answer to this question is to find a quiet place to do your homework. Remember that the place should be located in a distraction-free environment. There are some other factors too that create the distraction during your homework writing. Mobile devices are a major distraction for that. You should put your mobile phone aside. You can also put it into the silent or mute mode. Moreover, You can also use some apps that will lock your phone for a certain period. You can also do your homework with the help of some experts. Suppose that you need to have the statistics homework help. Then you can take the statistics homework help from the experts. They will help you to clear all your doubts more effectively. 6. Reward Yourself by taking the short brakes Majority of students don’t give the importance to the brakes between the study. But remember that brakes work as an amplifier for your brain. If you do continuous study, then you may not get the good grades. Because continue study usually tied up the brain. That’s why taking the short break always help you to refresh your body and brain. You should take a break within every 45 minutes during your study. The break should be as long as 15 minutes. During your break, you can walk around your house to get some fresh air. You should also drink some water to regain energy. Apart from that, you can also eat some snacks to fuel your body. It works as a reward for yourself and makes you more productive by doing something that you enjoy. 7. Prefer group study (If Possible) Sometimes group study works better than the self-study. The reason is in group study the members of the group help each other to motivate themselves and make them more productive. It also helps you to clear the doubts of each other if you find any trouble within the topic. Moreover, you can be sure that how much you have prepared for the exams. Because most of the time we assume that we study enough and get ready for the exams. But in reality, we may not be ready for the exams. On the other hand, in the self-study, there may not be any motivation for you. You need to motivate yourself. If the group study style suits you, then you should organize such groups. You can also do group study after class or on weekends. 8. Organize your study space In most of the cases, the students don’t organize their study space. It is a common thing that perfect planning leads you to perfect achievement. You should organize your study space efficiently. You can do this manage all your books and stationery in one place. Don’t you ever try to do not let your desk become cluttered with papers and stationery? Apart from that, you should also make separate notebooks for the separate subjects. Don’t you ever try to make the notes on the same notebook for every topic? Because during the exam sessions, it will be overwhelming for you to study from that notebook. Also, remember that when you prepare for the exams. You should always have your notes and your books along with you at the same time. In this topic, I also talked about planning. You should plan your entire day and divided into small parts. Along with that, you can also write down the important dates for tests. 9. Develop a study schedule Scheduling your study is crucial to get good grades in your exams. Whenever you decide to study. Then you should divide your time into small chunks. Small chunks help you to prepare for the topic more effectively. Suppose that if you’re preparing for the test, then you should divide your time into small chunks and put the small topic into these chunks. You should also manage the time as per the topic hardness. If the topic is hard enough, then you should give it more time, if the topic is easy enough then you should give it a little time. Majority of students were waiting for the last night to get prepared for the exams, but it is the worst strategy. Because no one can get good grades with a one-night study. 10. Take Care of Your health and stay fit Health is wealth for everyone, whether it is a student or a professional. Health is a crucial factor behind how to get good grades. You should take care of your health during the study. Don’t you ever try to avoid food during the study? Because your mind and body need nutrients for study. Therefore you need to make sure that your meals are nutritious, balanced, and varied. Because It works as a fuel for your brain and makes it more productive. Never miss breakfast before school because breakfast provides you the necessary nutrients for study longer. 11. Sleep well It is often that the students don’t get the proper sleep while studying for their exams. It is proven that sleep plays a crucial role in the performance of students. If the students don’t get the proper sleep, then they may not be able to keep their focus during the class study and self-study. Our brain needs proper rest. Therefore sleep helps the brain to relax for a couple of hours. Moreover, it also recharges our body and makes it ready for the study. It has been proven that the students should take at least 8 hours of sleep each night. It also helps them to stay fit and active during their study. 12. Utilize Your Textbook Textbooks are quite helpful in getting good grades. Professors and teachers assign textbooks based on some reasons. The crucial reason behind this is, textbooks works as a supplement to the lectures and discussions of the class. You should buy all your textbooks to study about the topic.Read all the material of the assignment topic it will help you to get deep knowledge of the topic. You should read everything about the topic from opening vignettes to the case studies. Also, try to figure out which topic is most critical. Also, try to highlight the most important materials in the text. It will help you to prepare for the exams. Conclusion Getting good grades in exams is not an easy task. There are some other ways too that will help you to get good grades in your exams. If you will follow these tips on how to get good grades in exams. You should not only follow these tips to get good grades. But you should also try your best to get good grades. All these tips provided by the academics help experts. There are some other ways too to get good grades without studying. One of the major ways is to attend your class on a regular basis. Because if you attend your class regularly, then you may be aware of the topic more deeply. And you can also prepare for the exams during your classes. In this way, you do not need to do extra preparation for the exams. Last but not least, I would also like to mention that you should also control your stress level. Suppose that if you’re not doing well during your class test, then don’t lose your hope and don’t get into stress. Because you still have a chance to get good grades in your exams.

It is simple to get good grades if you follow:  Network with intelligent and ambitious upper classmen took the class before youWhy? Inside information is key sometimes. Most professors have certain style of teaching, assigning homework, and handling tests. Learning this from the ones who already took class is vital.  Socialize with all your professors (greet them every lecture, go to their office hours, compliment their presentations, etc)Why? Professors are naturally inclined to give more tips and information to those he/she is fond of. It is a human nature. Use it.  Preview & Review (Preview the assigned pages prior to the lecture, and review them after; this is a lot more effective than cramming)Why? This is the fundamentals of success to college. Nothing wins over skimming over the material prior to the lecture, learn, and absorbing the information afterwards.   Do not procrastinate. That is not in your definitionWhy? Everyone says this for a reason. Listen.  Be physically and mentally fitWhy? Because good grades in college is worthless you are not healthy. Period. That is all you need whether you go to a community college or an Ivy League college.

I went to college, quite frankly, because people (parents, family, family friends) expected me to. I had no business being there; I wasn't especially interested, I had no idea what I wanted to do, besides some half-baked ideas, and I majored in Fraternity. (That means I spent most of my time in an alcoholic haze, seeking compliant female companions.) I graduated, thanks to credit by examination, with a solid "C" average. About 10 years later, I decided to seek a second BA with the idea of getting a Master's so I could teach after I retired from the Sheriff's Office. Despite working full-time as a narcotics detective and having a family, I applied the principles so well laid out by Elizabeth H. Simmons and others and got "A's" in every class I took. College is so much easier and rewarding when you Go to classDo the assigned readingPay attention to the syllabusAsk questions and engage the professorAnswer questions (You may very well be wrong, but if you are, you'll find out why.)You won't do well if you try to do it on auto-pilot. If you were able to coast through high school, like I was, you'll be in for a rude awakening when you get to college.

I have found that setting goals can result in incredible behaviour change. Getting a good grades at college boils down to three factors: Consistency: Highly underrated trait, but to really do well at college, you need to consistently put in the effort. Chilling in one semester, or even a course will not cut it. It needs effort day in, day out.Prioritization: You will have a ton of things to do. You need to pick your battles, and you can’t do everything. You need to prioritize, almost maniacally.Time Management: Even if you’re consistent and prioritize well, you need to manage your time. Devote time to personal well being and health, apart from academics. Trying to do any more is likely impossible.It is interesting that if you angle for a good grades,you begin to learn these skills. I call college a microcosm of life, in acceleration, because these are the very skills that really help you lead a happy, enriched life.

Lots of other good advice given.  Here's my answer. Let's work backwards.  To get a good grade, you need to do well on the final exam.  Starting a few weeks before a final exam, I will start to assemble all of the course materials in one place (or folder).  I will then make a list of all the topics covered in the course that will be on the final.  From there, I make sure to thoroughly understand every topic.  I usually need to pay extra attention those that I don't like, since otherwise I would be tempted to skip it.   If I didn't understand a topic the first time, then lectures/the textbook may have simply not explained it well and I will try to find the same material in another textbook or even better online.  There is a huge wealth of knowledge on the internet, and you can use it to learn more thoroughly and efficiently. The best way to learn specific topics is often through practice--especially true for science courses.  I will search out practice problems from the textbook and internet.  Practice exams are often the most helpful.  I will take as many practice exams as I stand or have time for. The final is not the only graded part of a course.  It generally a good idea to go class--even if you are not learning anything from lecture, spend the time reading the textbook.  Then you will not fall behind the course, probably learn the material better, and also hear important announcements.  To do homework, work with other students, get help from the TAs or professor, and start early.   For midterms I use the same strategies as for the final.  Even if you screw up a midterm, professors almost always count the final more heavily especially if you ask them.   Its even better to go the office hours for discussing course material and getting help when you don't understand something.  Professors want their students to learn and succeed.   Summary (this time in chronological order from beginning of semester): 1) Go to all classes.  Even if you don't learn from lecture, read the text during class. 2) Do all HW and do it well.  This way you'll learn and stay on track. 3) Get help from classmates, TAs, and you professor.  They want you to succeed and can explain topics in new ways. 4) Study hard for exams.  Make a list of all important subjects for each exam.  Know each subject and the types of problem relevant to each well.  Use other resources, and practice, practice, practice.  Find as many outside practice problems/tests as you can. Hope you find that helpful!  This is generally my philosophy toward to my coursework, and I would say its served me well.

I answered this question previously. Here is my previous answer: How I Study to Learn WARNING: This will not prepare you for exams. See the next section. This is the technique that I have developed that works for me. I enjoy a little bit of chaos and I learn by reading better than most people (find out your own learning style). I also generally learn things by myself so I rarely get to study in a group which is something I miss and would recommend if you can find a good study group. I also don’t have the luxury of a fixed time I can study since I have young children and work full time. Setup I make a list of different things I am trying to learn.I find multiple sources that teach exactly the same concept in different formats or different authors. (Textbooks, Books, Websites, YouTube, Online Courses)I try to have a big project of some type that uses what I am learning.Now I have:Multiple concepts to studyMultiple resources for each conceptA project that covers multiple concepts.Study I have my list of resources to go through and I either pick one at random if I have not studies for a while or cycle through them. Then I follow the same procedure: Study the material.If it is too hard go back to easier material or…If it is too easy skip forward.If it is boring or if I am finding it hard to focus go to the next resource.If I feel like I have made significant progress then work on my project and apply what I have learnt.If I finish a resource or finish the part of the resource that I care about I take it off my list and put it in an archive area for later on.Repeat until I run out of time.The aim is not learn everything the first time through (you will probably only remember 25% of it if you are lucky) but to generally understand it. By learning the material multiple times from different sources you increase the amount you retain overall and can apply. There are diminishing returns from doing the same thing multiple times so I generally only have about 3 resources that cover the same thing. Generally you will go over the same concepts again as you cover advanced concepts so I try not to stress about it. Exam Preparation WARNING: This is of limited use if you do not know what you are doing. Preparing for exams is completely separate from learning something. To prepare for an exam you are trying to prepare for the edge cases / obscure questions. To learn something you are trying to learn the general cases. I think preparing for an exam is generally a waste of time / inefficient if you don’t understand what you are being examined on. Focus on learning it first (a long time before the exams) then closer to the exams focus on preparing for the exam. First of all you need to get at least one of the following from best to worst: The Syllabus (What the course is supposed to be about)Rubric (How the assessment is supposed to be marked)List of topics. (What will be in the exam)You may have noticed that your teacher’s advice is NOT on this list. Never rely on your teacher. They are human and make mistakes. You need to take control of your education and be proactive. This does not mean that you should not listen to them. They will give great advice BUT don’t rely on them. This applies to university as well as school. Go through the list and make a list of things: You think you know. Then give yourself a short assessment on them to see if you actually do know them. If you fail the assessment move them into list 2 (below).A list of things you sort of know.A list of things you don’t know at all.You can largely ignore list 3 for the moment. People learn concepts faster if they are related to things we already know. This means that focusing on things you sort of know will: Get you higher marks. A mark is a mark.Make study faster since you will learn these concepts faster.Make study easier since you already sort of know them.Generally things are related so as things move from list 2 into list 1 it will also move some things from list 3 into list 2.Things in list 3 are basically a failure to learn a concept. Take them and go back and learn those concepts (See How I Study Learn). So how do we quick learn things in list 2? Generally they are edge cases, facts that you need to remember or processes you need to apply. Here is what I do: Facts / Edge cases: Flash Cards using a SuperMemo system. You can use the app or use 3 piles. (current, recent, archive)If a card is correct 3 times (I use pencil marks) move it to recent.Once your current pile starts to get smallish go through recent. If any of them are wrong move them to current and reset the counters. The ones you get right move to archive.Once every now and then go through as many archive as you can stand before you get bored. If you get any wrong move them to the current pile.Process: I find example problems (past exams are great) and solve them. Question with solutions are often hard to find so make sure you don’t cheat yourself. If you need a worked example try to go back to a previous answer you have seen and use it to check your process. You can never unsee an answer.Hopefully you will have notices that this is a generic process that you can use to learn anything and you can use it forever. This is called lifelong learning.

Hey. Thanks for the question.  Honoured to receive Gold Medal🏅at ECE, NIT Surat! I've always aspired to be best at everything I do. This spirit and thought leadership encouraged me to strive for excellence in my undergraduate college (NIT Surat). Starting from first semester to the last, I employed the following techniques to secure good grades: Maximize attention & retention in class- It was always my first priority to clear and strengthen concepts/fundamentals at the very first attempt while being taught in class. I prepared notes extensively during the class itself, and also always focused attention towards grasping and remembering as much as I could.Frequent brief revision- Not to leave critical portions to the last hour before exam, I briefly revised them once a fortnight to stay in touch with the content and numericals. I used to identify important questions and numericals while reading from the book or presentation for the exam and revise them again during exams.Effort variability- Every semester, I would use the first few days (~2 weeks) to figure around the difficulty and subsequent comfort level of the subject. Once identified, I would focus on difficult subjects more and schedule easier ones during times/moments/days when I felt discouraged or not wanting to study. This way, I ensured proportionate focus on all subjects for consistent results.Exam pattern & expectation- Ensuing from my class experience and previous year papers, I tried to always understand what concept is tested in a variety of tests across all subjects. This way, I knew really what to expect and eventually intelligently prepared.Focus on laboratory and project work- I always exerted myself to understand the application of various concepts through practicals and projects. It is often difficult to maintain motivation consistently, but atleast knowing the eventual deliverable and the enablers required is important towards finishing the same. Taking initiative is of utmost importance, undoubtedly.Time management- It was always important to me that I strike a balance between college PORs, academics and extracurricular endeavors. Being able to manage time and orient efforts efficiently is extremely important to doing well in one's UG college.Really hope this is helpful! Let me know if you need any further help. :D

It's possible for anyone to get good grades in college as long as you learn to develop study skills; but it also depends on how much you're interested in the subject at times. Studying a subject that isn't your favorite (or that you aren't naturally interested in) can be more challenging to learn than studying certain subjects that interests you naturally or you're naturally good at learning.  For instance, in the past, I had to take and pass a college algebra class to fullfill a college requirement. Math was never my favorite subject, but I can do the basics an can remember some elementary thru intermediate algebra. I struggled very much in college algebra class, and even tried asking my professor or another professor for help. I believe this was like an introduction to calculus. So, I only got a "C" as my final grade. However, I was able to get "A" grades in other classes. If you really want to get good grades, you should always aim for an "A" grade or at least a "B" grade and study hard.  Suggestions to help get good grades for traditional classrooms: - Get to class a few minutes early or on time on the first day and the rest of the semester.  - Attend classes regularly, because the professor typically provide lectures on new topics every class; and you don't want to miss this part, because the professor may mention something important in the class that's not in the textbook. - Read the syllabus, especially the important course information, including class work /homework deadlines, professor contact number,  other resources, etc. - Write notes during lecture in class. - Participate in class discussions, and ask the professor questions especially if you need clarification on something. - Read the assigned chapter readings before the next class. Complete any assigned homeworks on time.  - Having some good time management and organization skill to organize your calendar for assignment deadlines, midterm or final exam dates. - Usually the professor would give a study guide for final exam, and this can help you to review and study the important topics. - Go to tutoring lab in your college if there's one available for your subject,  and if you need extra help in certain areas. Lab tutors usually provide help in Math subjects, English, grammar/ writing, proofreading, reading, and computers.  Online classes are somewhat different, require more independence, and can be more challenging than traditional classrooms as well; but same skills are also required to get good grades.

In high school, you could pull out your notes a couple of hours before the test, look at them, and get a 100 without really studying at all. In college, if you have a rigorous major like science, you can't do that. You need to do pre- and post- class work. Pre work: What will you be learning tomorrow? Read ahead in the book tonight. You already understand some, and you know what you don't understand. Unless you go to a lecture hall type of school, you are in a classroom and can ask questions. When that topic comes up, don't be afraid to ask your questions. If you are still lost, ask one of your lab group/ study buddies if they get it. If so, have him/her explain it. Maybe a peer explanation will resonate with you better than the teacher's. Also, it will help your friend realize what the gaps in his/her knowledge are. I did my Master's Thesis on this. I called it: Peer Tutoring and the Tutor Learning Effect. You will be helping out your friend, too! Post work: Review notes every night. Internalize what you understand and prepare questions on what you don't understand. After your post work is done, do your pre work for tomorrow! It is a lot of work, but my students get straight As so it works!

Never miss a class. Ever.Sit on the front row so you can't doze off or be distracted by your phone or laptop.Take notes with a pen or pencil and paper and record the class digitally, if you can. Listen to the lecture again later while you review your notes.Transcribe your own notes into a more legible form.Get to know your teachers/professors. Go to their office hours. Let them know you want better grades and are willing to work for them.Ask for extra credit.Treat school like a job at a startup company or political campaign. Spend way more time on it than you think you're capable of spending. Don't slack. Know that it ends someday, so just push through now.That means study. Study more. And study some more.Join or form a study group. Study together. Talk about assignments together. Collaborate in an ethical way (don't cheat, in other words).Force yourself to go to bed earlier and get up earlier. Exercise. Eat somewhat well. Don't do drugs. Drink in moderation. Be healthy, and you'll perform better.

1.   I would call the professor before the semester started to get a list of required readings. I read those in the weeks between semesters. I annotated a lot. I underlined and wrote in the margins.2. I seldom missed class. I  showed up sick, I showed up when I had to shovel three feet of snow to get to my car.3. I took good notes. I take shorthand, and if I wanted to I could have transcribed the entire class. But I was selective  and copied important points. After class I typed up my notes.4. I paid attention to what the professor was saying and how he was saying it. I looked for what was emphasized, repeated or written on the board.5. I am interested in memory techniques like Loci, Chaining and Pegging. I memorized the material as I went. I made sure to learn each day and each week’s material. I did not cram before tests. I already had earlier material memorized.  6. I played classical music during study sessions. Today I listen to “study and relaxation” music on youtube while I am reading. writing or memorizing. 7. I take deep breaths before and during learning sessions. Conscious, deep regular breathing helps me to sleep and to study.8. I used affirmations. Everyday I looked in the mirror and told myself how smart I am.9. I was a vegetarian then and i am a vegan now. Eating right is important too.

This really depends. You mean best grades compared to your peers or based on the traditional grading scale? I will assume you mean the latter (based on the traditional scale). So really, you’re probably talking about an A or A+. Step 1) Go to 100% of the classes. Step 2) Sit in the front of the class. Step 3) Take copious notes and keep them all in one place. Step 4) Develop a rapport with the teacher. Step 5) Contibute to class discussions (avoid being “that person” who doesn’t shut up, though; there’s a happy medium). Step 6) Do ALL assigned work to the best of your ability. If an assignment falls short (by a low grade), meet with the teacher and find out how to improve for the next one. Step 7) For all upcoming tests and quizzes study with a partner and/or a group. Step 8) Discuss the material of the class outside of class. And use supplementary materials to enhance what you are learning. Step 9) When taking the tests, try and take your time and give it 100% effort. I am convinced that if you do all of these things, you will get the highest grade possible. Good luck!

I was very average high school student.  Didn't care.  Didn't work.  Might have been average anyway, but that is what I was.  My dad knew I was scared about going to college, thinking I would not make it.  No lectures, no long speeches, he just said, "I made all A's by doing only one thing: never get behind.  Do today's work today.  If you have a M-W-F class,  don't wait until Tues to do the work assigned Mon.  Research papers have to be planned by dates, then do all the work by those dates.  College is easier than high school in that it is more objective, but it is harder in that the work just keeps coming and will bury you if you get behind.  Stay current, and it will be easy." He was right.  I never thought about whether I was working hard or not.  I just did what I had to do on each day to keep current at that point in time.  Social things were determined by that, not the other way around.  I found that I worked much less on weekends than my friends had to, and I never had to cram for an exam.  Grades were great, life was good.  Most stress free time of my life. So, just one sentence: Do today's work today.

I think I have a high enough GPA for me to answer this with some credibility. The following are things I usually do that I have seen other people with high grades do as well: 1. MAKE A SCHEDULE. 2. MAKE A SCHEDULE. Yes, it's that important. Schedules of when your exams are, when assignments are due, when you plan to study for a specific course during the week - they all help reduce stress and increase productivity. Planning ahead = less cramming = better understanding of concepts, with better grades as a by-product. 3. WRITE WHAT YOU LEARN. I have consistently noticed that when I don't write down information I just learnt about, I forget them ridiculously fast. Writing also helps you notice intricate details in math problems, word choices in definitions etc. which increase your comprehension of the topic. 4. PROCRASTINATE. Yes, please do procrastinate, but "efficiently". Give yourself breaks to do the things you want to do (like watching that new episode of " Sense8"). Give yourself rewards for hitting your goals (which you listed in your schedule obviously!!), and it will help you relax. 5. DON'T GO IF YOU DON'T NEED TO. I am talking about lectures, tutorials, help sessions etc. I have seen a lot of people attending every single thing their school calendar lists out. I personally think that it's better to study at home  than go to the latest tutorial if you are ten lectures behind. Use your time how YOU want, based on YOUR needs. 6. APPLY YOUR UNDERSTANDING. You just learnt this really cool concept in your calculus course, but have you tried relating that knowledge to what you are learning in your signals course? Making stronger connections across courses boosts your understanding of the concept, so always try to look at a bigger, better picture. That's all I can think of right now. But the above should be a good guideline, one I try to follow very rigorously.

Take advantage of the tutoring centerMost colleges have them. Track down the tutoring center on campus whenever you need help, need a refresher on something or just want to review before a big test.If there is no tutoring center, then suggest to the campus to create one. In the mean time, you could ask your professors to recommend resources for study help.Talk to someone in the major you need help inAs mentioned above, professors can help when needed.But also, you could try making some friends with other people. Those in the same major (or even same class) could be potential study buddies/study group-mates. Pick a time & place, sit down together and study! Alternately, you may have a class with other majors in there and you could find someone in the major you need help with. You could ask nicely for help or recommended tips/resources.Cater to your study styleThere are psychological tests online, in doctors offices, etc that can tell you what kind of student you are. Are you a visual, audio or hands-on learner? Do you study well in a quiet place or somewhere bustling? Find your study habits so you can set yourself up to a good study session (ex: if you’re a visual learner who hates noise, study with flashcards in the library)Peppermint oilWeird little tip but this REALLY helped me out during exams and some other people I know like it. Peppermint oil has a strong tie with concentration and memory. Try sucking on some candies made with peppermint oil. If you can’t stand the taste, then buy some peppermint oil fragrance and put a little on your hands, then sniff.Stay hydrated, exercise 30 min a day (3–4 times per week) and get enough sleepStereotypical advice but GOOD advice nonetheless. Your brain won’t be able to learn if your body is falling apart. Healthy body, healthy mind.Also research suggests that people have a better study session after they’ve settled down from a work out. Blood’s pumping to the brain, less energy to make you fidget, oxygen circulating, that kinda stuff happening.

The foundation is simple: 1.) Attend every class 2.) Be on time to every class 3.) Sit in the front row in every class 4.) Participate in every class 5.) Finish every reading assignment With that, the rest will come easy. But the key is understanding grading. For example, letter grades for projects and exams mean nothing — at least at Cal. State Long Beach — because final grades are calculated from a pool of points, and each project and exam is worth a different number of points. To start, calculate the number of points you need to earn an A, which is 90 percent of the total number of points available. Then gauge how many points you need on each project as the semester or quarter moves along. Don’t waste your time translating the points you earned on projects and exams into letter grades. They mean nothing. The only thing that matters is the number of points you earn at the end of the semester or quarter. For example, if you bork a project early in the semester that earns 10 of 20 points, that would translate to an F. But the final grade in the class is based off a larger pool of points, say 600. So you lose those 10 points — big deal. You can make them up later easily, so don’t get bogged down in the minutia. Focus on the big picture. By the time the end of the semester rolls around, you should know exactly what you need to earn an A. Sometimes you might need to do extra credit or work extra hard on your final project. Other times you might have so many points you won’t need to take the final exam — happened to me twice. But if you look at the big picture — the total point allocation — you’ll be able to create a study strategy that fits your situation, which is how you maximize time in the end-of-semester crunch. Additionally, use in-class note taking as a filter; take notes of the important stuff and leave out the rest. Thinking critically like that in-class will help you absorb the material and take better notes. Also, rewrite what the teacher says in terms that make sense to you — your notes don’t always have to be verbatim. Finally, take classes that interest you. Sometimes a stinker is required — take it online, if possible. But when given a choice, take classes you like.

Sleeping is CRUCIAL for good study performance, better study 2 hours less and sleep 2 more.Spread the work. It’s only a fool that goes to the courses and doesn’t remember anything afterwards. Learning starts in the lecture, not afterwards.Make connections with what you already know. You basically remember things by making associations with things you already know. It’s pretty effective, but don’t force it, it must be spontanious.Study 30–60 minutes a session and take a 5–10 minute break. You’ll have to STAND UP when taking the break, and don’t youtube, just please don’t.And one thing: please don’t read your textbook, it’s not a novel. You can highlight or make a summary when learning, but don’t just go through the textbook specially for it, because it takes a lot of time for retaining very little.Using the same pen for studying the course and taking the exam will improve your ability to remember. And change sometimes from study enviroment, instead of always studying home, go an afternoon to the library, or sit for some hours at another desk, as it will improve your learning.Don’t forget, imagination is the key to everything.Hope this gets you somewhere, and I apologize for my errors, as English is not my native language. Good luck and damn just think about what you can achieve!!!!

SO many with serious answers. This answer going to be different than anyone else. I tried their ways, but I find it making my grades even worse. So I did the opposite (except for being relax). Relax: One of the thing that most people forget is this. If you are stressed, you tend to get very distracted to other things than the subject and also tend to forget things easier. Just don't get too relaxed.Never procrastinate on revising or studying: Well I find some people gets good grades when they procrastinate, but the problem is that they might not understand things (because they are likely to copy whatever what they study) at last minutes. When people don’t understand enough, I don’t think they’ll be able to explain properly when they come across a question they never know.Don’t become a revision zombie: This links back to the first and second point. One of the reason I wrote not to procrastinate on revising or studying; gives you more time to relax since you have more free time to do.You don’t have to be great to start: If you think that you need those damn-expensive-practice-book-or-something-related, its not really required. You could use plain papers and make up some questions for yourself (and the best questions are probably the ones you don't understand).
