You have everything what you need.

Looks like you have been studying to remember. That said, no matter what method you used, it is simply ineffective because you are just trying to remember stuff from whatever notes you wrote or material you watched. The key idea is to have a sense of direction in your studies where you know exactly where you need to study each time in your study session. This will allow you to study to understand instead of studying to remember. Start by setting certain times on certain days that you should be studying. This allows you to be more organized in planning your studies, play time and work. Now I am not talking about a school timetable or a daily timetable where you have to follow every hour of it. What I am talking is that you have to pick certain hours of certain days that you MUST be studying/preparing for exams. Example: Back in my studying days, I have always allocated Monday 11am - 1pm, Wednesday 8pm - 10.30pm and Saturday 9 am to 11.30 am, all with a 15 minute break in between, for studying time. This allows me to be very organized in knowing how much time I need each time to do my studies every week. A three hour long studying time with a 15–20 minute break is appropriate. Do not plan or attempt to study continuously for more than 3 hours at a time because you will eventually become disengaged. In the last 10–15 minutes of each studying time, you need to do some reflection. This involves you reflecting back on what you have studied or what you have learned and what you still need to learn or perhaps what topics that you may require your lecturer or your classmates to help you. Thus, a reflection after each study session gives direction on where you have learned and where you still need to improve on learning. This will allow you to plan your next studying session that focus more on the topics that you need to improve. So naturally you are constantly focusing on improving rather than reading an entire book or memorizing stuff. Hope this helps.

If you are struggling with grades and interested in raising your grade point average, take a close look at these 10 tips for getting better grades. 1. Attend every class If you want good grades in college, you must attend every class, not almost every class. The importance of regular class attendance cannot be overemphasized. When you miss classes, you miss lectures, notes, discussions, explanations, and assignments. Do not think that missing a class won’t make a difference. You cannot make up what you miss. 2. Master Your Professors Every professor has a different personality and system for running his/her classes, so it makes sense as early in the semester as possible to learn what the professor wants. Here are some ways to master your professors: Understand course expectations. Most professors give out a class syllabus during the first week of classes — and it is your responsibility to know deadlines and all the requirements for the course.Understand professors on personal level. Rather than viewing the professor as some figurehead at the front of the class who decides your fate in some abstract way, get to know your professor as a person. Visit him or her during office hours, or stay after class.Communicate with professors when you are struggling. Especially at larger colleges and universities, the professor won’t know when you are struggling, so if you are having problems with the course work or the tests, schedule an appointment to meet with the professor and get the help you need.3. Be organized: Use a student planner: take this to each class and record all assignments. Also use your planner to keep track of tests and quizzes, activities and appointments.Break down assignments: large assignments are more manageable if you break them down into smaller parts. Completing these smaller portions over a longer period of time will allow you more time to focus.Use three-ring binders for class notes: this type of note book works well because handouts can easily be inserted and if you end up missing a class you can also insert a copy of someone else’s notes where they belong.Organize and save computer work: make sure that all your work on the computer is saved and saved often, and that you have back up files.4. Use Time Wisely Even if you do not procrastinate and are the most organized person in the world, time can be one of your biggest enemies in college. Here are some tips for using time wisely: Don’t overextend yourselfBe organized: see number 2 above!Schedule 90 minute study sessions: set a specific time to get your studying done and make sure you will not be interrupted. During these study sessions, don’t do anything else but study!Make ‘to do’ lists and prioritize tasks: make a daily list of the things you need to do. Rate each item as an A (must do today), B (should do today), or C (would like to do today, but can wait). Listing and prioritizing your tasks only takes a few minutes but it is a great way to organize your time. Focus on one task at a time until everything is completed5. Take Good Notes: tests usually cover materials that the instructor has presented in class. Therefore, it is important to have good class notes. Be an active listener: when your actively listening, your not just hearing the words, but you are also thinking about and trying to understand the information being presented.Taking notes can help you pay attention and stay focused.Recognize important information: anything the instructor writes on the board is important. In your notes, underline or star the most important information so you can pay special attention to it when studying.6. Know How to Read a Textbook: Knowing how to scan, read and review will make it much easier for you to understand and remember what you read. Scan: scanning gives you a quick overview of the material you’re going to be reading. To scan, read the title, subtitle, and everything in bold and italic print. Look at the pictures, captions, charts, graphs, and read the introduction, the summary and the review questions. Read: when your reading has a purpose, you have a reason to stay focused and your comprehension improves. Review: to review, first ask yourself ‘what is the main idea’ and then go back to the beginning and go through the same process you did when you scanned the material. This time, as you scan restate the main idea of each passage using your own words. 7. Study Smart: Students who study smart find themselves spending less time of studying and still getting better grades. Find a good place to study: make sure the area is free of distractions.Know your learning style: we all learn differently! Some learn best by seeing the material (visual learner), some learn best from hearing the material (auditory learner), and some learn best by doing (kinesthetic learner). As a rule, the more senses you involve and the wider variety of methods you use while studying, the more you remember.Organize your study time: before you begin, make a plan. Decide exactly what you want to get done. Always allow more time than you think you will need and prioritize your work to make sure that you have enough time for the things that are most important. Do difficult tasks first while you are most alert and fresh and remember to take regular short study breaks.9. Be a Good Test-Taker Just about all college classes have exams, and sometimes the exams are the major portion of your final grade, so it’s important to become a good test-taker. Here are some hints: Know what to expect on exams. Every professor has a style of test development, so obtain old copies or ask the professor directly. Know the types of questions that will be asked — as well as the content that will be covered.Read questions carefully and plan answers. Take your time at the beginning of the test to read through all the instructions and make a plan of attack.Pace yourself so you have plenty of time to complete all parts. And know the point v alues of questions, so you can be sure to complete the most important ones first in case time does run out.Ask questions. If you don’t understand something, or need clarification of the question, ask the professor. Don’t wait to get the exam back and find you answered a question the wrong way.Here are some tips I think it may help you a lot to get good grades in college. Yet, each one has their own style of learning, there are no fixed rules in learning. Find yourself anyway suitable and sufficient to your own.

Actually the best people to ask are 1) your teachers, 2) students making good grades. You should be reading and doing homework on a regular basis. Other than that I can only tell you how to learn and write more effectively. That should help your grades. 1) The best way to learn, is to teach someone else what you are trying to learn. 2) Create tests for the subject. Most students stick with memorization and their “difficult” questions concern unnecessary details. Create knowledge application and problem solving questions. 3) Condense the information into the briefest form you can and still recall what it is about. One day before the exams review notes. take a small 3 X 5 card and write down everything you think you should know for the exam, but do not know. 4) Convert data that must be memorized into visuals. My daughter had this book with picture images of all the state capitals. Her favorite was a hairless (nude) hamster boarding a Concorde jet for Concorde, New Hampshire. 5) Look for what is ironic or humorous when you read long passages. This makes it easier to remember. When it comes to writing, I’ve described how to organize writing, without making it dry and boring, in my blog. Deciding on a direction There are other things that go into grades besides how well you do on papers, projects and tests. Teachers and other students would know what these additional expectations are.

This is effectively how we studied during undergrad and college and applies practically for all liberal arts degrees. 1/ Make friends with all students on your course. Yes I mean all of them from day one, this might be or seem hard to do but you'll realise why later. 2/ Collect everyone's essays (good grades, bad grades, in between, terrible grades). 3/ Read and dissect all of the essays understand why things were marked positively or negatively, start looking at writing styles 4/ Spend time with all your course mates and help them / share the information about what is working or not working across the board 5/ Produce a checklist of what to do / not to do in essays and exams going forward, distribute this to everyone on your course, they will love you for it. You will be able to quickly and clearly identify patterns, writing styles and techniques that broadly cannot be "copied" but applied using your own voice, form and tone. 6/ Make friends with students on your course but one or two years ahead. Repeat steps 2 - 5 What this does is help you identify upfront how to spend time and resources in order to do the best and maximise for grades. This will save you time / energy and also let you pursue other interesting activities at College. It is not all about the grades even if it can feel like it. The above advice is not to be abused, do not start blatantly ripping off other peoples work, plaigarism is the biggest academic sin. You also need to find your own writing style, studying habits and build good relationships with professors for references and career advice post-graduation. Good luck!

It's not mysterious. Study hard, follow the professor's instructions, go to every class (and pay attention -- this is not a time to check your email or Facebook page), seek help from a teaching assistant, the professor, or peers if you're struggling. Study groups are sometimes helpful. Try to take as many courses that you enjoy as you. Don't drink to excess (or probably not at all except on weekends) and don't do drugs. Get as much sleep as you can.  In other words, be responsible.

Don't try and do it all yourself. I don't mean cheat or plagiarise, but work with your colleagues. You aren't in competition, and between a group of 5-10 of you, you can cover so much more academic ground, and share the main details with each other. Swap notes, essays, discuss it over coffee. The way the system typically works in the UK (in Arts subjects) is that you cover many aspects of a course and are tested on different bits in different ways throughout the year - i.e. you can do your coursework on x and y, and answer your final exams on a different topic. If you did x and your friend y, why not swap before the exam so you can learn from each other? My best lecturer at university constantly drilled this into me and made it clear that for large and complex courses there was no way we could learn enough by ourselves (possibly some of the brainiacs could for exam reasons, but in general not enough for any of us to satisfy real academic thirst ), but if we worked together everyone would win. At the end of the year he was investigated for cheating after over 90% of the class got the highest grade. Professors from other universities spent weeks double and triple marking our exams, and they all found that the spectacular results weren't down to generous marking but down to great learning and a deep understanding of the course.

Read and apply the text book Becoming a Master Student. There is no such wizzard out in the world who will sprinkled over your head “magic dust” that will help develop the SKILLS necessary to thrive. Much of your success will present itself following LONG hours of hard work. However, you can follow these 3-steps which have and still work for me: Show up everyday to work no-matter what with a sound mind, and if you don’t have one that day—show up anyway and do the work. Remember, it’s not about you in college: It’s about completing the work, so make sure your major is a subject you are passionate about.Always do and complete your homework. Remember, you are stronger than you think you are.Hang around with people YOU want or desire to be come like. They will become your professional colleagues. If you want to become a rocket scientist, (STOP hanging around old friends) find others who want and are willing to do the work, or they are already rocket scientists.

Here is what I can add to the excellent responses.    Do your prerequisites in the suggested order!Really master the English comp classes, most of your upper division classes will require a research paper.  What was an unbelievable chore as a freshman became a breeze as a senior.  When I could crank out a paper in 2 weeks rather than half a semester, I got much better grades.Use pre-session and summer classes.  I found that concentrating on one subject for 4 weeks was far more effective than 5-6 subjects over a whole semester.  I learned the material better, got better grades and graduated sooner.  I once took a 2 week pre-summer session class.  It was 8 hours per day, the mid-term was the first Friday, the paper was due and the final exam the next Friday.  The second Monday was a holiday; I spent the 3 day weekend writing the paper.  If you do nothing but one subject for 12 days, it's amazing how much you retain.If your school offers video classes, use them for things outside your major.  You can watch the videos while resting or eating and read the chapters the night before the monthly in-class test.  If the videos are available for download, DVD, or tape (showing my age), watch the video for the next week before the test, it often contains a review of the test!

karthik Kanna, not knowing any details about your high school academic background you need to know that when you go to college you have to put in a tremendous time for study of your classes. Your primary reason for going to college is to get your degree and depending on what your academic background was in high school, what you want to major in in college, how fast you learn, and how much time you 're willing to put in to studying determines your level of success. You as an individual have to be willing to put in whatever amount of study time that you need to to make good grades. According to "Has College Become a Riskier Investment?" in Econ Focus, third Quarter, 2013, by Renee Haltom, there is a 50% drop out rate of student across the nations college campuses because they're not willing to put in whatever amount of study time they need to to make good grades. You also need to be aware that the decades old high school diploma is being gradually replaced in the United States labor market by the 4 year college degree. Please read "It Takes a B.A. to Find a Job as a File Clerk," in the New York Times, February 19, 2013, by Catherine Rampell.

response.answer_text: Most of my experience is within the American college/university sphere. It’s very hard to tell you how to get high grades because everything depends on the individual professor. Keep in mind that most American college grades come out twice a year, at the end of each semester. The professor has one semester to teach, which is about a 4-month period, more or less. He/she may choose to give one final exam, which counts for entire grade. Or there may be two papers due, one at mid-semester, one at the end. Or maybe five tests and one presentation. It all depends, but as a general rule, there are fewer grades to count towards your average than in high school. If you don’t understand the prof’s expectations, the first thing to do is visit him/her during office hours and ask for help and explanations. Attend every class, every extra session, and keep working hard. If you need general help (how to write a paper, how to prepare for an exam), most campuses offer a study center with people who can give you pointers. It’s all on you to do your best and there aren’t that many opportunities in a given semester.

College is universal and that means, it's an atmosphere where you can come across anything you'd ever want. Be it partying, shagging (lol), sleeping, traveling, whatever you really want can be done at your discretion. Now you've gotta: Transform your Discretion to being a DUTY! I've got a book: The Academic god. In it, I learnt all I'm gonna share with you. Understand who you're lecturers truly are. What they'd expect from you in answering his exam questions.ROTE STUDY. Take this very seriously. ROTE means “memorization by repetition” . The courses you'll offer per semester, no matter how voluminous or so many of 'em, they all can be stored in your memory through Rote Study. Here you gotta memorize your books as often as possible. This demands a great amount of discipline.You gotta study all over & over again until you get totally engrossed in and beyond (although closely connected) to the Course Outline. 3) You gotta if you'd want, DRAW UP A PERSONAL TIME-TABLE. Here, you set the time range to study that best suits your daily activities. This had helped a Good number of Academic Giants I've encountered. 4) Always have 1st hand info. On any assignment, Project, anything connected to your coursework. And more importantly, you get to PROMPTLY DO ALL ASSIGNMENTS & avoid copying your neighbor. This gives you TOTAL INDEPENDENCE & CONFIDENCE to excel in your exams even though you're sitting with your Dad as a mate. Lol 5) Study ahead in & out of session to grasp the Substance of your coursework for the next semester. This is gonna give you an edge over those who would be first timers to the class discussion. 6) Understand your body. How you assimilate, what to eat to help you stay up for long hours to study. You also have to know when to eat and what to eat. This is also very essential. For example, here in Nigeria, I love Garri & Soup very much, but I dare not eat it sound 5pm because it's so heavy and when I sleep, if be too heavy too get up. Even though I wake up, I'll be dizzy and I'll sleep again. But when I have just Bread & A gaseous drink, I'd wake up in 1 hr 30mins time. And I'll be greatly energized for the night shift. So it's SIMPLE! HOLD ONTO THESE AND YOU'LL BE AN EAGLE! Yours sincerely, Abam, Miracle. Rivers State University.

There are many tips on how to make A’s in college, I have read and researched but these are the new amazing ones I discovered, they worked for me and they can also work for you. 1. Be Motivated: What is your motivation to make A’s in College? is it to please your parents/sponsor, to feel good about yourself, or to get a good job. Make it known to yourself. Believe that you can achieve whatever you set your mind to, remember what this great man said, Whatever the mind can Believe and Conceive, it can achieve Napoleon Hill Write your goal out and paste it where you will see it anytime you want to start studying, it will motivate you to study harder because you really want to achieve that set-out goal. 2. Take Responsibility: College life is like a different world on its own where nobody will tell you when to study or attend a lecturer or even read your books. Everything is in your hands. Since grades are everything in College, take responsibility for your grades in college, know when you need to study, have fun, hang out with friends, visit your professors, be awake at night, do your chores, etc. (more)

Grades and schools in general are pointless. Main objective is to have skills and knowhow. Good grades at school and college has nothing to do with how successful you’re gonna be at your work. Schools which are preparing for your future job won’t teach you how to do it. So it’s pointless to concentrate on how to improve your grades. You can be a programmer(self thought) with high salary even with an elementary school if you can do the job. On the other hand if you have diploma for being a programmer and your only interest was to have high scores on your exams and nothing else most likely you’re be bad at your job and you’ll get sacked and nobody will hire you afterwards. What good is your diploma with high grades now? Believe me, I was there myself so I can tell you from my experience..

Some of these answers sound good but are impossible to do. Other are long lists that you'll forget 10 minutes after reading them. How about 3 steps. 1. Sleep. Enough with showing off all-nighters. You won't be able to focus if you don't get your rest. Therefore, you can't memorize or remember as well which leads to bad grades. Use this site to calculate what time is best to go to bed. sleepyti.me  2. Social Media. It's tough not checking your phone every 30 seconds but once again, it wastes time. Better yet, it may waste time your taking away from sleep. Try this: Moment - Track how much you and your family use your phone on the App Store. There are other apps available but if you see just how much time you spend on your phone, it may motivate you to stop. Not completely, but try to check it after a certain time. Like 8:00. 3. Finally, the usual. Don't cheat. Don't wait until last minute. Instead, use the world of Quora to learn in a more interesting way. Most people on here can teach you what you are learning, just in a more fun way. All you have to do it ask. Use the search to see answers on how to study better or tricks to make complex mathematics easy. Now read this post over and over and over until it's drilled into you conscious.  Cheers!

Do you want to attend a prestigious university, or do you thrive in competitive situations? Think about the factors that motivate you to perform at an academically high level, and set realistic goals that are challenging but attainable. A few ideas for academic goals include finishing every reading assignment before class, getting straight As in every class for one semester, pursuing extra credit assignments or keeping your grade point average above a certain level. Rewarding yourself is a great way to stay motivated. Rewards can include buying something for yourself or even going out to dinner with friends. You might even involve your parents as accountability partners who reward you for academic success. Despite the challenges you may encounter, such as difficult assignments or a low quiz grade, remember to stay committed. Instead of having a pity party when things go south, chart a path for future success and take action.

Don't think that reading something over and over again is studying Many students study by simply reading the material they are trying to retain over and over again. The thing is: that is really ineffective. If you read something over and over again you don't memorize the information but you rather just become more familiar with it. That means your brain tells you "Oh I know this, I've read this before. This is easy." when repeatedly reading something. (As you can tell, I'm not a brain expert and this is oversimplyfied) Test Yourself Instead, test yourself on the material you want to memorize. Do that by just flipping the page or covering it up and then asking yourself "What did I just read? What is the information I'm trying to retain?"  If you want more tips on how to study better, check out Learn Studying.com - Learn To Study More Effectively And Improve Your Grades!

There’s no easy way to improve your grades, but you (and everyone else) can do it. Here’s a list of things you should start to do that will result in your grades rising, although it won’t necessarily happen quickly. Start to behave in class and pay attention. This is the first step, and it will help more than you know.Move you seat closer to the front so you can listen and won’t be as distracted by other students.Learn to take notes trying to identify the major points your teacher is making.Write down your assignments and do them every day.Begin to ask questions in class that are thoughtful and help you understand better.Work on these five ideas first. See if they don’t make a difference for you. Keep at it for a whole marking period and then let me know who you do. If you get back to me, I’ll come up with some next steps for you. Remember, there will be no instant moment where you start to experience success. You’ll need to keep working at it. Good Luck!

“How to get good grades?” – Students often struggle with this question when they sit to study. Sometimes it is hard to adjust to a new environment and score good grades. It is quite evident that every student does not study in the same way. Even the brightest students can find themselves academically underperforming. Make your presence known in the class Most students don’t tend to participate or even skip their classes for one reason or the other. But you need to understand that your presence and attendance points can reap sweet fruits. One of the benefits of regularly attending all the classes is that you build a guiding relationship with your teachers which can have direct impact on your grades. Apart from this, it is equally important to be involved and make efforts in class discussions and debates. Justify buying all your Textbooks Have you ever wondered why are textbooks assigned? They are not for overloading your bag but for a major reason of helping you to score well. 90% of the question papers are set from the textbooks only. It definitely becomes easier during your exams if you have gone through the material of all the assigned textbooks. Therefore, it is important to use the outlining system to help understand the material. Merely reading and highlighting the material is just the minimum. To get the most of what you’re reading, you should also take notes. For more, you can read here: Are you struggling to get good grades? - Educolada Stand out and mark a Difference Educolada - India's Eductaion Portal

There are lots of excellent answers here going into the details of what to do, but there's something important and somewhat counterintuitive that I think is missing: The best way to get good grades in college is to not care about grades. Remember that you're not going to college to earn grades; grades are just a way for professors and yourself to keep track of your progress. The reason you're going to college is to learn things, to acquire new knowledge and new skills.  So make it your goal to achieve this! Don't focus on your grades, but instead focus on how well you're doing in each class. Be honest with yourself: are you getting a thorough understanding of the subject? do you remember the material? can you work out (on your own!) the answers to typical homework questions? If you can do these things, you'll get good grades. If you can't do them, the good grades are meaningless.

A2A This question has been answer many time in Quora, so I am surprised that you didn't check out the many answers including my own. Study habits and hard work is how you get good grades in college. It is understanding what is expected and how you are being evaluation. The latter depends on how well you can learn from your instructors. It is a fact of life that some instructors are better than others. You can find out from other students who have taken the class or google the instructors name and see reviews. What I did to get my A's was to carefully select my course load. It is important that you don't take courses that demand a lot of "lab time" at one. You have only a limited amount of time outside of class. Since I was a math/computer science student, I took only two of those classes at a time. Filling in the rest with other courses. I also look for overlap between courses. It is easier to take required course that overlaps so can focus on the readings and assignments with less work, leaving more time for my major. As for as each class is concerned, I interviewed my instructors finding out what was expect as documented on the syllabi. I read all the material before going to lectures so the lectures were review and I took notes. I then review the notes and got help from the instructors in open office hours. I also found the best students and form studying groups with them where we went over the answers and prepared for the tests. This takes a lot of time, so I was in the library everyday usually until it closes, roughly 60 to 80 hours a week including lectures and labs. My solution was to getting good great was hard work. This may or may not work for you. Bottomline: Getting good grades is always to play to your strengths.

response.answer_text: I love this question because it shows that there are actually quite a few people who want to get good grades as opposed to actually learning. I'm going to tell you a story. In high school, I had an AP biology class, which was my favorite class I had ever taken. Why is this, because I learned a wealth of things, and so fast. This hasn't happen like that before in any other class. In the end, I got a C+ in the course, but I could explain back everything that I learned. Now in the same course, there was another kid, who looked like he as falling asleep, playing games, and goofing off, but he got an A.  In this case is learning better than the letter grade? Yes it is.  The secret to learning is to love the thing that you are being taught.  I'm not saying be a C student, but I'm saying a grade might not show people's learning gains.

Take a moment to care for your body and by extension your mind. Get plenty of sleep Eat properly (stop with the cheap french fries and other greasy foods) Drink lots and lots of WATER. Stop downing coffee and caffeine drinks. Get outside and breathe fresh air. Get exercise. Walking is great idea. Next, focusing on the actual education side of things. Sit as close to the front as possible so that you can decrease your distractions. Take notes. Review notes. Highlight things the teacher repeats (probably important) Get a study-buddy. Test each other. Get a tutor if you really need help understanding. Talk to your teacher. See if there are some extra credit assignments you can do to boost your grade.

Think of it as a job. A regular job with a 40-hour or more work week. How is that possible? You get classes for 16 or 18 hours per week (perhaps with couple of labs). How is that a full-time job? Because the person who is going to teach you the most in college is YOU. Unlike high school, where the teacher meets with you every day and guides you through the entire course, step by step, a college instructor will expect you to do a lot of the work of learning on your own. That is what your syllabus is about. At the first meeting of any class, you will receive a syllabus. It is a complete outline of the course, telling you what topics will be covered in each class or lab, when all papers are due and when tests and exams will be given. It also sets out the grading criteria, and tells you the office location and hours of the teacher. Each teacher will have a certain number of hours each week he/she is in the office available to answer questions from any student. If the teacher’s office hours conflict with your schedule, the syllabus (or the teacher) will tell you how to go about setting up an appointment when you can meet. It will also list the required reading. And if you look, you will see a lot of required reading. The general rule in college is that for every hour you spend in class, you will be expected to spent an hour and a half studying outside of class. That is why a 16 hour class load is a full schedule: 16 hours in class plus 24 hours outside of class (16 x 1.5 = 24) totals to 40 hours total studying time, in other words, a full work week if you do it the way you should. So schedule yourself those hours of studying time. Get a week planner and lay out, each day, time for class and time for study. Designate which periods of study time will be used for each class. Decide where the best place to study for that class would be: your dorm room, the library reading room, a study room or lab. Then follow that schedule. When your dorm mates come by and say, “Let’s go out on the lawn and play frisbee,” look at your schedule and say, “Nope, today I have to work on my (paper for my psych class, reading chapter 14 of Palmer and Colton for history, those calculus problems that are due tomorrow, etc.) There will be times when you will goof off and go play frisbee, that’s okay if you remember that you will need to make up that time later. So play frisbee now, and write down in your schedule a time that you will make it up in the evening or on the weekend. Note: your college may have different expectations. If your college requires 20 hours of class time for a full load, then it expects you to study one hour on your own for every hour of class. If it requires only 12 hours a week. that means the faculty expect you to study between 3 and 3 and a half hours per class hour (to be precise, 3 and a third hours, or 3 hours, 20 minutes). You can find out the expectation of the college by looking at what it considers a full load, and realize that the expectation is that the average student in that college will work 4o hours or more every week on studying. One of the great benefits of this study plan is that it will eliminate a tremendous amount of last minute pressure. It won’t eliminate it all. Sometimes things take more time than you expect and you end up in a rush, but if you stick to the schedule, you will find that happening less and less. It worked for me!

When my sister-in-law enrolled in college, she asked me for advice.  I ended up writing a blog post for her based on my experience as a professor and a student:  College tips: advice from a professor The quick summary:  Beware the first semesterDon't confuse professors for teachersGet aheadFight procrastinationPay attentionWatch your healthOptimize your scheduleRegister earlyTake courses from the best teachersLearn LaTeX (technical majors)Confront your weaknesses

I am a professor, so I suppose my answer is quite relevant. There is a popular saying, "For however many hours you are in class, you have to spend double those many hours after class studying/reading" While that might be a nice thought, it isn't really feasible in this day and age. What's a more reasonable approach that I tell my students is to just use a factor of 0.5x if you want to receive at least a B+ in my class. A typical student has me three times a week for two hours. That means that the student should spend at least one hour that day after class, reviewing all the notes for the class, and reading further chapters. This is if I didn't assign any homework, if I did, then obviously spend enough time to complete the work well.

Mainly organization and time management. The main difference between college and high school is the amount of work outside of class. Plan on spending more time outside of class than you are in class. You can do well (A or B) in most classes by spending 1 to 2 hours studying or doing homework outside of class for every hour in class. Hard classes sometimes require over 2 hours outside of class for every hour in class to earn a good grade. Also, you are better off studying a some every day than trying to cram for tests; you will also learn more and retain it longer.

Assume responsibility of this thing. College isn't care for secondary school. There's no instructor or guardian to help you consistently to remember what you have to do. So venture fixing to make something happen and assume liability. What grades you get will rely on upon what you yourself do. Study like you would not joke about this. At college, you're relied upon to set up an hour or two (now and then more) for every class meeting. This implies planning the time every week and discovering a proper "study environment." No gadgets, no long range interpersonal communication, no companions, no eating—only your brain up against the work. We know this can be difficult—yet all understudies who get A's do this (no matter what they tell you).

College is definitely an amazing place as the exposure is immense. Of course securing a good grade is important . It's not necessary to attend a class if the lecture isn't worth . As a college goer I feel we need to be self motivated to get good grades. Remember no one is going to push u to study , unlike in school . Get to what your syllabus is before hand . Take down short notes while studying . Mugging is of no use . U need to have a Thorough knowledge of the concepts. Form a group with ur good friends and get all your doubts clarified. It's not necessary that you study daily but be as sincere as possible while doing ur assignment. Do not copy from friends. Professors are definitely approachable . Get ur doubts clarified without any hesitation. Library is the best place for resourceful learning . Get to know from ur seniors the best reference books and go through that in your free time . Start your prep for exams at least 2 weeks before it's start .Have confidence in yourself and be focused. Get going man!

Treat school like a full-time job. Set up a study schedule and stick to it, to the extent that, if something comes up and you have to miss a scheduled study session, the first thing you do is to reschedule that study session. If you were getting paid by the hour and needed the money to eat or pay the rent, this is what you would do—take your studies that seriously! Next, go through the syllabus for each course and schedule all due dates for assignments, tests, papers, and projects on your calendar. Now you can back-map extra time into your study plan. You will be more efficient and less stressed. Finally, squeeze a little time into your day and week for yourself. You need adequate sleep, nutritious food, some exercise, and some personal and social time—just keep these things in balance. You’re in college to learn, but some of the learning is about how to manage your life. Good luck!

You go to all your classes and pay attention and take notes. Do do all the assigned readings and complete all the homework and turn it in on time. In college, you will probably spend more time per course than you ever considered spending in HS. Enjoy your free time and meet new interesting people. BUT, make sure you don’t get carried away by your new privileges - REmember that all night party can become addictive and hurt your GPA. Watch your drinking - keep it to a minimum. Pay attention to your life and how it impacts your grades. In other words, be responsible.

There are tons of things you can do to improve your college performance. I’ll focus on one in particular: Get extra help in a one-on-one format if you need it. If you don’t need it, get it anyway. Reach out to your professors, teaching assistants, colleagues, and whoever else you can whenever the opportunity prevents itself. These types of conversations will help you build well-rounded, informed opinions and will help you refine your work. Spending ten minutes after class with your professor to discuss a paper draft - or even your concept for a paper - could be the difference between a B and an A.

Take (or work out the prerequisites toward) classes that interest you and that you can be or become passionate about. All the rest is just details, all the rest will just fall into place. After that keep in mind that no one (including employers and, to some degree even grad schools) care what your grades were in college, the people who matter want to know what tangible things you did, what projects you completed, what research you were involved in, what leadership roles you took.  They want to see real things, not numbers or letters.

My formula was this:   1. Attend class. 2. Read the assignment, and participate in class in a way that reflects you read and thought about the assignment. 3. Don't pull allnighters.   4. Study something you don't mind doing for a couple hours a day so you don't have to cram. Note that last part might mean good grades at the expense of job prospects, so it's a balancing act.5. Perspective - tying course material across disciplines, especially on written exams, hits a lot of top-of-the-curve grade buttons - I suggest a background in greek mythology/philosophy for an endless supply of comparative examples to give answers context. It's familiar and applicable to every course, including technology and science.

Go to class. Every class.  Take notes, do the assignments.  Read the syllabi and be organized. Don't let assignment due dates or tests sneak up on you.  Be engaged. Don't just occupy physical space in the class.  Get to know your professors. Spend time with them out of class. Engage them. Learn from them. Don't just talk about class subjects. Speak to them about life.  Get regular sleep and eat well.  Get extra help is you feel you are not understanding the material. Go to the tutoring center, library, wherever you need to go to get extra help.  Hand assignments in on time. Always.  Don't rely on spellcheck. Learn how to write. Use college to help you with that. It is critically important.  Did I mention go to class? Always go to class.  And, if you really, really want to do well, research the subjects beyond what you are reading in class. Form a study group. Work with your peers and learn from each other.  All of the above will not only help you "get good grades," but also prepare you for the world post-college.

Cornell Notes are very helpful. All of your questions go on the left side and your notes go on the right. You have a summary box on the bottom that simplifies what your notes are about and at the top of the page is the title, objective and date.Form study groups with those who have similar problems. For an example you are stronger in math than I am. You help me with my math and I’ll help you with your science.Set goals for yourself and reward yourself when you reach them. An example would be you making an 95 on your final exam and you reward yourself by watching your favorite show or doing whatever you like to do.Focusing on your strengths rather than your weakness because when you focus on the good everything will fall into place.Never give up. Its ok to take a break every once in a while but you should never quit.I wish you the best of luck

There are several ways to obtain better in higher education. I would begin by talking with successful upperclassmen within your major. Find out from them how to effectively maneuver through your curriculum at a high level. I would also form an alliance with worthy peers that maybe taking the same courses as you. Surrounding yourself will help as well to collaboratively achieve better grades. These skills will definitely help you with networking as you matriculate through your university. Lastly, apply yourself a lot more to studying and learning. Instead of studying a subject, actually learn that subject. I believe that this will help with the retention of information.

Take care of yourself. Eat well and exercise regularly. Always make time to sleep. Most college kids forget about that.Make good friends who are serious about academics. Stay away from the stoners and the hard-core drug users (I am serious about that).Be disciplined about how many fraternity or sorority parties you attend each semester. I am not saying you should not go to any party. Just know your limitStudy smart. Some professors test from the books. Some professors test from the class notes. Know thy professor and you know what you need to do next. Do not equate the number of hours you sitting in front of the books with the grades you are going to get. If you are not absorbing the materials, get up and do something else for a few minutes. If you are not getting the problem sets correct, don’t be shy to ask for help.The weekend is BOTH to relax and to study. Sorry, hate to break the news to you. Straight A’s students do not take the weekend off. They don’t study all the time on the weekend but they are steady. Everyday they squeeze some studying in to keep up the pace. College is a marathon. Not a sprint.

There a lot of descriptive answers here ranging from study habits to daily routines. I am taking a direct approach for answering the question, how to get good marks. The biggest mistake student make is they keep reading reading and reading and complain "I did so much and put so many hours in my work yet this is what I get", and they stop pursing grades feeling dejected.  So the trick or moreover the truth is,  its not completely about reading its analysing! When you study remember its 70% analysing and 30% reading.  When you analyse  the more deeper you dig, the more deeper you dig the more better you remember stuff, the more better you can remember stuff the more you recall, and more better you recall, the more better you write! And when you write better, they have no choice other than to give you marks. Voila! you have your grades :) So remember the rule is 70% analysis and 30% reading!

One study method I used consistently, as an undergraduate: I took detailed notes in lectures.  If I did not have another class following immediately, I went to the library or the union (usually, it was too far to return to my dorm room), and finished the notes right away.  I then read them over and abstracted them, for major themes, relation to the course readings, and areas that I did not understand. If I could, I reread the second version of these notes in the period immediately before class section meetings.  I made a short, scratch-paper list of topics to ask about in section, especially areas that I didn't understand.  I them brought these topics up in section, gaining the explanations that I needed, and a reputation for being interested and persisent (as well as, on occasion, dense, when it took me overlong to master a concept).  This is particulary important, since the graduate student teaching assistants have a great deal of influence over final grades, especially in large classes. For exam study, I went over my notes, including my notes on section discussions, ONCE, on the evening before the exam.  This worked well, especially for essay exams, which were the way the majority of my classes were evaluated.  These notes also fed into term papers, though in a less direct way, since research and synthesis, as well as referencing and bibliography, are more important for papers. I maintained the equivalent of a 3.2/3.4 GPOA as an undergraduate, and was, later, suvccessful in graduate studies.

The way to get good grades in school is simple and difficult at the same time. First read the chapter before class and take voluminous notes during class. Review your notes daily. Go through the review sheet for the test and answer all the questions thoroughly. That'll get you an A in most classes. Some classes require natural ability. Those classes don't respond to traditional techniques of study. For example, higher-level math and expository writing. You have to have some measure of ability to do well in these. School, however, is mostly about discipline not smarts.

Assignments Do assignments as accurately as you can. Research thoroughly and read extensively on the topic. This helps you gain broad information on the topic and a general understanding of it.You can study with these assignments when exam time comes.It minimizer note making time too.Notebook Have a notebook where each modules has its own space. Or a file where you file all assignments and marked tests in.Exam question papers Look for past question paper so that you get an overview of the structure, mark allocation and popular questions that are normally asked.Identify a pattern in these question papers so that you know what to expect and you study sections that you know will definitely appear. This cuts down on studying things that won't appear and gives you time to master content that is sure to appear.Write these papers and then mark them. This will help you find answers and show you your mistakes. You should learn from them.Color/Colour People who use their right side of their brains more can study using colour. Use highlighters and colour pens to take notes.Facebook, Twitter , tumblr and instagram (I think, correct me on this one.) use blue as their colour. That is why you can spend so much time on them because blue is a soothing and calming colour. It's not harsh. Use a blue pen when writing your notes and exams papers.Recording Record yourself reading important concepts and notes. Listen to them wherever you go.You will end up mimicking yourself word for word on those notes.Laugh Before a test or exam I'd watch YouTube videos of puppies and kittens. I'd watch funny ones too just to laugh.There are also those videos that make you laugh till you cry. Those ones just help me relax. Writing an exam is stressful enough on it own. So, don't try and act composed, you are just making it worse by worrying. Laugh a little before a major exam.All the best.

All the studying in the world will not guarantee better grades. You may be just spinning your wheels by using the wrong techniques. You must understand your personal learning style. We do not all learn the same way. Strangely, many good students are unaware what they are doing right. If you put forth the effort and still get poor grades, you probably need an assessment of your learning style. Ask a college advisor what resources are available to you. I’m telling you this from experience. I finally got tired of lousy grades and was determined to figure out what I was doing wrong. Instead of graduating again with C grades my degree says “With High Honors”. Go get help.

The more you are intelligent the more knowledge you get and that's need little hard work as your brain doesn't need to work to much as you easily get the point. Asking questions during the sessions help you Remember that for long. But as good grades are concerned that only depends on hardwork the more you study ,the longer you give time to studies and improve your concepts about litttle thinks could improve your grades. But It doesn't mean that we just study the whole day that's not gonna work either. Taking a break,refreshes our mind by doing our favourite things, listening to songs taking some high carb food for healthier brain. In this way u can study for longer and your grades might improve.

Learn for the sake of learning.  You will hate some subjects and possibly lose the motivation to study (or even show up) because you'd feel the subject is useless and a complete waste of time. Try to fight the feeling by reminding yourself that you learn the subject for the sake of learning it. :) Show up in class.  When I was an undergrad, I realized that I got higher grades in classes that I attended religiously, than in classes I was sometimes absent in.  Don't take things for granted. Every extra credit, every quiz, every homework matters. Imagine missing an A by 0.1 just because of that one homework. Hurts, right?  Have fun.  Don't forget learning is fun, and you're not in college forever. :) Good luck!

No big formula just a short trick.. “Dont be serious , be sincere..” Which means dont toil hard on the last day before exam but just be punctual and study less everyday..Consistency is the key..This is an basic rule we all know but we dont apply basics even if we know it..So begin with it..ur grades will surely become good..Again u must have some motive to study … Eg… To make my parents proudTo lead a comfortable lifeTo live with prestigeTo get highly paid .This may vary person to person..but having one is important..If u cant find it atleast remember u will regret not following this basic on two main days of ur life..Before the exam nightOn result dayAnd may be the rest of ur life..So the choice is in your hand now..Thank you..Hope it helps..Avoid grammatical mistakes..M slowly learning..

You need 2 study as if u are a monk! That means having a quiet (no media)place, good lighting, a chair that keeps ur back straight, u can breathe well and also be comfortable. It will b important 2 take breaks- walk a bit- no thinking of academics! Hydrate at this time as well, otherwise lay off snacks till it is time to eat. Focus ur mind on what ur doing- no thought of past/future. only the subject at hand. These things should b a routine to b practiced over and over, so that they r a “real habit”. Make and keep it REAL- it should b like a. long, repeated mantra- the same thing over and over. The reward will b in the grades as well as ur overall understanding of academics- this is ur future at stake!!! Your study is a practice just as important as going to class-it is like going to class again-can u hear the prof. teaching?

As a parent and a former student, I strongly suggest contacting your professor and explaining that you've gotten off on the wrong foot, and have realized you need to be more attentive, and ask what you can do to bring up your grades. You might not be able to bring up your grade to an A (sometimes, you can), but you could possibly pass. Then, when you have time during the course of your studies, you can always retake the class for a higher grade, especially if it's the only "low" one you have. I used to settle for low test scores until I realized that my teachers were willing to work with me; no one wants their student to fail, and most will find a way (although extra work will probably be involved).

Find others to make friendship with who are concerned as you.  Become partners with man or women leaving sexual feelings out.  When 2 or more people can be a study group together.    I  got better grades going to the library together where there was quietness to read, write or ask each other questi ons about subject matter. Try to be always restful , the brain takes in more data  that can be stored- remembered.  Test each  other every so often & devise simple tricks to correct answers in relation to a certain question   like rhymes.  Eat healthy, sleep sound & hang out with the above. You'll do well.

Read, listen to pod casts and watch videos. Preview material and review it. Practice doing something over and over until you master the task. Get to know your professors and offer to provide them with support and assistance on any of their projects. Be respectful of them and show appreciation, gratitude and humility. If you need help, don’t be afraid to ask for it. In short , be emotionally intelligent and build relationships with people who can help you reach your goals. And focus on your priorities. In this life we all reap what we sew.

response.answer_text: Here are five practices that help: Understand what the teacher is looking for.  Getting your priorities straight.Have friends who care about their grades.  Peer groups are key.Use your time effectively.  Try to do 30 to 90 minutes for homework everyday (reading, studying, writing, etc..)Know how you write the best.  Also, if you are in a humanities or liberal arts degree, pick classes that interest you.

There isn’t one set answer to this. Everyone has their own style. You will just have to discover your method on your own. I get together with college friends a couple of times a year. Some studied every day, some studied for a set number of things a few days a week, some studied better under pressure. We all have various careers. There is no formula. If I had to suggest any piece of advice, it would be to keep socializing in check. Many students let fun and independence take over. This can lead to a bad GPA and having to drop out. Beware of the temptations.

Use a daytimer and enter all assignment due dates, and all tests for the term -- all the better to visualize them and work towards them. Maybe everyone's doing it these days with iPads. I never saw anyone doing it in the 80's. Plan and enter in the calendar your study times in blocks and keep to the program. A paper timer is better, because you can "check off" your study times during which you are on task. Evaluate after week #1 if you're keeping up, or need to modify the schedule. Self monitoring (i.e., accountability) promotes performance. Get to work on term papers early. Really early. Right away early. This prevents the build up of anxiety, prevents rushing. Let's you do more reading. The more preparatory reading you do, the more those papers seem to write themselves. Exams? I could never cram. I started my review 10 days ahead of the exam. That way, I was nearly done by the time others were just starting. It also unnerved them to say "I'm nearly done" when they asked if I've started preparing. (I was competitive back then). Getting the jump on exam preparation really relieved test anxiety, as I just "coasted" up to the exams with a little light reviewing the last couple days, to make sure "I still (had) it." Also, once in a while, there's the rude shock of realizing there's something you missed, or really don't understand -- better to find it a week before the exam than the night before hand. Doing these things took me from a B to an A student in university. Good luck in your studies.

The college has a pleasant and difficult experience. On one side, classmates are always ready to throw another party. But on the other side, professors are giving you more and more assignments. Maintaining good grades in college can be difficult. These are the tips That Help you to get good grades in College: Attend all courses you have enrolled in.Sitting there is not enough for improving your grades in college. For this, you need to be active.If you are in a bad academic situation, the best thing to do is to speak with professors.Make the learning fun that helps you to get good marks.

Discover how you learn best first by trying each learning style: Overview of learning styles Then, after each lecture, try to obtain some materials pertaining to the lecture, that match with your best learning style. This helps in retaining the knowledge. Find out which subject you’re naturally good at, then put more effort in the ones you find difficult. This will help balance out your overall evaluation. Remember though, that grades aren’t everything. Not all of us are good in all subjects, but that doesn’t mean we are intellectually weak. After all, you can’t judge a fish by its ability to climb a tree.

There is no shortcut to getting good grades, it involves hard work and perseverance.You have to be serious and give a few hours even if it is just 2 hrs, and study with complete concentration.Know your syllabus, take notes when the professor explains things.Try to clarify all your doubts and do not take classes for granted, thinking you'll go home and figure it out.College is diffirent as you know what you like and you've chosen that field of study as your major, make sure you interest doesnt waiver.Ask for help with reports and assignments you cannot complete.Make study groups with your friends, and discuss topics , help each other out. Hopefully this should help.

It’s easier than you thought. If you know the right tactics and strategy. Studying in college can be hard. Remember that you are not alone. I have helped thousands of students with the right strategy to get 4.0 GPA. I also share all of these tactics and strategy for FREE here, if you’re interested to get good grades immediately. Define your goal"Arise, awake and stop not till your goal is achieved"- Swami Vivekananda. If your aim is just to get marks then be mad to get it and forget everything. Obstacles are those frightful things which you see when you take off your eyes from your goal. Do your work with full concentration otherwise just leave that work. Rest you must check the previous year to get an idea of how hard or easy your test could be. Intelligence is a good thing but don't shy away from hard work. Study, Study, Study! Make sure your studying at least 10 times a week the more you study the better your results will be. I would say read ahead you want to read before the next lecture so even if you don’t know about the subject at least you have read. So when the professor lecture over it you will at least get an ideal of what the topic is about. Doing applications problems is another way to ensure that you will do well because you want to make sure you can solve the application problems that could be put on an exam. Make mock tests Do practice tests to see how would you score on a practice exam that way you can have a indication of what you need to review. Ask questions visit office hours discuss anything your struggling with to see how could the professor help you. These tips worked for me My professor uploaded grades today and I got a 4.0 for the semester

An interesting statement was made by someone on Quora that asked the same thing.  He said that his professor said that    "...Grades are a measure of how much faith one has in the educational system...". Which seems kind of profound to me.   If I was going to extrapolate advice to you out of that, I would simply say do whatever you have to do to make the college educational system work for you.   Just don't cheat or steal.

1.) Begin every project assigned as soon as it is assigned and concentrate on it till it is finished. Refine it as you get ideas between finishing it and its due date but don’t be shy about handing it in early. 2.) take notes in class and recopy the notes in an organized manner easy for you to review every day as soon as possible after class. Highlight the textbook. Review the highlights and notes every day. This will take only a few minutes most days. As you become comfortable with your notes rewrite them again in briefer more condensed form. As the test day approaches you will only make a brief review of the last few things you have any difficulty remembering. 3.) When you study math of physics read the text actively, that is, do every calculation the text demonstrates rather than just reading it through. 4.) Never miss class and never be late to class. 5.) when you can, tutor students who are weaker than you. This will cause you to really learn.

Aspiring to have good grades at school and in fact in overall academics is what everybody wants. As you want to achieve good success. It's better you organize your routine. Getting good grades is not just about being a bookworm or else say spend most of the time studying. No!! You shall inculcate habit of smart study, quality study. Do participate in extra-curricular activities because they will build up your personality. Take mock test and practice self-study because it's far better than attending any coaching classes. Be disciplined! I hope this points will work for you. And I m sure that as you are determined to gain good grades you will achieve it. Good luck!

Do your studying and other work away from where you live. Find a study hole in the library and make it your place of retreat. You will be surprised how much more you will get done away from distractions. Ask questions during and after class. This will not only make class more enjoyable and interactive but will help you fill in the gaps of your learning. Get involved in a study group. Study groups help you focus on the specifics in the subject and can help illuminate your ignorances.  Don't be afraid to be wrong and be open with your study group. Actively try to find a note taking and study method that works for you. These strategies are not one fits all and what works well for one may not for another. One strategy I found that worked was reviewing my notes immediately after class and highlighting what I was not confident in. Hard work. It may seem like a cliche but hard work does often pay off in the end.

3 quick tips that help me:  Immerse yourself in the material: watch videos in your spare time, read blogs, ask questions outside of what's on the slides, contribute to discussions. This will open your mind up to understand the topics more broadly.Solve problems before starting the material: it's a psychological hack. Do problems before learning, like practice tests, and your retention of the material improves.Be strict with yourself and others: when it's time to study, sit your butt down and study. Turn off distractions (like Quora) and try to concentrate for a set amount of time (you'll find you don't have to be up all night if you can spend an hour and a half without getting distracted). Don't let friends sway you into "leaving for a snack break" before you're ready; if your Saturday night was dedicated to studying tell them so.

You will need to read all your assignments carefully, and follow the instructions. Even if teachers do not give homework, when you get home from school, review what the teachers showed you in class. Make sure you understand everything you are being taught at school by asking questions, and practice at home. Practicing means the same thing as studying. Spend as much time at your desk at home studying as you do playing games or watching videos on your computer, tablet, or phone.

(I'm assuming it's a typo, and if you mean “college”- ) Actually listen to the teacher.Make your own notes (never rely on others).Don't chase 'quantity' study time, rather opt 'quality' study time.(Quantity- long hours; quality- short hours with concentration).Always discuss with peers.Teach. Find a student (a friend) and explain to them what you already know. You'll get a better grasp on the topic.Use internet in a best way possible .

Work hard, participate actively in class, always do homework, never miss a class, listen to the lecture, be respectful to the professor and other students, appreciate what you are studying, don't think what you are studying will be useless in the future, and don't let yourself to get negative influence from other students (like those students who say things like, “Come on, you can study tomorrow,” or “It is not like studying will help your grade or your future,” etc.), be sure of yourself and what kind of achievements you want to aim at, stay positive. Oh, and don't cheat.

The most important times to influence the grades that we'll earn are at the beginning of every term and the beginning of every day. At the beginning of every term, separate at the staring gate. Postpone social activities until after the first mid-term exam. Hang out with other diligent studiers at the library. Make fun of people not studying as hard as you are. (haha) Never miss a class.Sit in the second row in class. (Stalkers sit in first row)Focus on earning the best grades you can on 1st MT's.When others panic as exams approach, relax and smile.And when exams are done, ask yourself how it feels to be prepared as possible. If it feels good...Do it again!(You can also relax a bit to celebrate your results with fellow diligent studiers)Good luck!

My CGPA is 8.51 I think it may be Good grades. So I'm  eligible to answers this question.  How I study in semesters examination of my University.   I explained through point wise.  1. I collect syllabus of my course.  2. Going regular college, I'm not generally bunk class.  3. Study those subject on room which is running on my College.  4. Generally I prepare subject before my Class teacher end subject in class.  5. I mostly Prepare Hand written notes from Standard Book  6. I also preper Short notes of each subject which helps in short revision.  7. I also doing some exercise for good health & taking fruits daily.  Note :- 1. Self study is very important.   2. Study Regularly don't miss any day.  3. Study any topic conceptually, if time Taken then give time on that topic.   Hope it helps you.  Thanks.

Go to every class. Participate. Ask questions. go to office hours. Ask your teacher questions if you don’t understand. As you listen to lectures in class notice the buzz words and jargon the teacher uses and incorporate those words into your own every day speech and in the papers you submit in class. While grading of things like math and physics is more about getting the correct answer, other subjects allow the instructor to be more subjective as to the grades they give and if they get to know you and your style it certainly doesn’t hurt.

Go to class - every single one. Do the assignments and hand them in - on time and neatly typed.Look as if you're listening in class - participate in the discussion when discussion opens. Smile and greet your professor as you enter class if it's a small class and say 'thank you have a great day' as you leave class.Don't ask for any extensions on papers. That's a good start and you've gotten a host of good answers.

response.answer_text: Achieving high grades is what we all want as a student. However, sometimes we are having trouble recognizing what is the best way for us to learn and absorb the lessons. One way to know your learning styles would be attending a tutor center or hiring a private tutor who is an expert on the course that you are having trouble with. Developing students’ critical and independent thinking skills will make them perform well academically and eventually recognizing how they learn effectively. There are different tutor centers in Hong Kong so you must be meticulous on whom you will trust your needs with. This site may help you on your problems. Visit http://www.allround-edu.com/tutoring-services-hong-kong/academic-tutor/

Re copying and annotating your notes is an excellent place to start. But it requires a level of discipline that not many people have. I don’t. Study with people. Specifically, try to identify the second weakest student in the class. If you commit to studying together and you can teach the material to this person well enough for him or her to pass, then you can get an A or thereabouts. Don’t focus on the weakest person, because that person will likely drop the class.

Study hard by regularly reading, reviewing and questioningStudy smart by reciting studied material out loud, possibly in a study group, and forming questions which possibly could be on a testBe focused on your educational or career purpose or goalInvest in your classes by participating in class and meeting with your professors after classLook for opportunities to do research in your undergraduate major by studying with a professor you admireBy your junior year do a study abroad, coop or internship

A lot of great points have already been given that I really wanted to make, so I’ll provide you with these two tips: Try your absolute best to not wait until the next day to study what you reviewed in class. Study the material as soon as class ends as that is when it is freshest in the mind.Eat a balance and nutritious diet and avoid skipping breakfast, the most important meal of the day.

Be a good steward of your time! College is often the first time students are completely responsible for budgeting their time, with no parental input, support or nagging. Be sure you balance what you must do with what you want to do. Find like minded students in your classes, and form study groups. They are a lovely way to combine work and pleasure. College life is full of temptations. Keep uppermost in your mind that your goal is to learn, and to put to good use all the money that is being invested in your education. Enjoy the experience - all of it!

I utilized the “read ahead and study when it is not needed.” I was also a frequent library visitor. I studied and researched and therefore, prepared myself for a busier end-of-semester period. Students should study with one another. Find the students will similar goals and objectives. This accountability partner will help you get through your program with better than expected outcomes. Pay attention to all that is around you. Strategically engage in activities and programs that advance your internship and future career opportunities. Write a plan and check in on your plan at the beginning and end of each semester. Change your goals and objectives based on advancing each semester and years’ goals.

I can tell you the answer to that bc I’m a junior at this point and it’s real simple. Study! Study! Study! I can’t stress enough, study and time management is the sure fire way to make good grades. Also take advantage of any free tutoring or your professors office hours, I have yet to utilize those bc I simply don’t have the time. But if you do, please so if you’re having trouble.

Asker, You can get better grades at college by really working and studying hard and if you out all of your focus into your work and if your really put the effort into all of your work and you are determined to do well then you will get the best grades. You will a,so get th beets results if you aim for 100% attendance through the college year and if you remember not to take holidays during term time. If you aim to please you tenders and upport workers when you are at College you will also get the better grades. Thanks, Francesca

College is a tough life and challenging. Mostly, this is a phase that will make or break you. So dont forget to brace yourself. Focus. Its the hardest but the surest way to have a good grades.Make a strategy plan. College life is a battle, so make sure you are ready. Strategy or a study habits. Have fun sometimes. Remember, all works and no play makes Johnny a dull boy. Relax sometimes, you will get through as long as you will keep your study a priority.

Motivate yourself. ...Listen and participate in class. ...Take thorough notes during a class. ...Do not hesitate to ask for help. ...Stay focused during your homework. ...Take a 15-minute break after each 45 minutes of studying. ...Consider studying together with your fellow students. ...Keep your working space organized. Don’t fall behind, don’t procrastinate, don’t pull an all-nighter before a test. Find your best learning style and use it to the fullest advantage. If you want good grades in college, you must attend every class, not almost every class. The importance of regular class attendance cannot be overemphasized. When you miss classes, you miss lectures, notes, discussions, explanations, and assignments. Do not think that missing a class won’t make a difference. You cannot make up what you miss. Maintain a neat and organized study area: Set up an area or desk with everything you will need and keep this area clean.

I may get negative feedback for this, but I've seen serious students succeed by doing this. If you have a difficult course scheduled for the fall, take it at a community's college or online over the summer so you aren't seeing the material for the first time in the fall at your college. Premeds often do this with organic chemistry and prelaw students do it with philosophy. If you have a tough literature course coming up, try to get the reading list from the syllabus and read most of it before the semester starts. Use professors' office hours, tutors, math and writing centers, dummies books or whatever you have to do to master the material and the skills. Do not be afraid to ask questions and get help with study skills like memorization if your school offer students a study skills course. It will help you with time management and study strategies. Good luck.

If good grades is all you need than I have a great strategy: Study the grading system and figure out what are the factors on which grading of subjects depend.Study the question papers of previous exams, see if you can find any pattern or important topics which get repeated.Study according to the question paper and its pattern not by the syllabus. See if you can find who is going to evaluate your grade, And adjust accordingly to their nature and style of teaching. Use pictorial representation to boost your answers eg. diagrams, sketches, etc.Hope this helped.

Study, Practice, and Comprehend. Study the material in a SMART (Specific, measurable, attainable, realistic, and timed), goal-oriented way. As one who received both good grades, as well as bad grades in college, I learned that there’s almost always a reason why one makes good grades: preparation for tests. A2A, thanks. Determine whether you have any gaps in preparation (prerequisites) for a given course.
